It's always bittersweet replaying this one. It's poorly balanced. The combat is a slog whether you enjoy how it works or not. They shamelessly pad the game length with hundreds of tedious, pointless enemies. The game is riddled with bugs. Crashes. Corrupted Saves. Constant restarts of the game to clear bugs like dialogue skipping. All of these things will probably happen. 

In contrast to that; the game has cool cut scenes, stellar voice acting, a story and dialogue that are at times super engaging. The characters are great, the settings and writing are true to the universe. Any Star Wars fan can find things to love about the game.

I love and recommend this game, but if you're only going to play one KOTOR game, play the first one. Definitely don't play this one before the first one if you've never played either.

150030124.review: With TSLRCM, it's the greatest Star Wars game to date. Its nuanced writing and dense shades of grey philosophy are leaps and bounds ahead of its predecessor (which was well written mind you.) KOTOR 1 felt like a traditional over the top, swashbuckling, good vs evil kind of Star Wars tale (very much in line with the OT) whereas this one is a deconstruction of regular Star Wars stuff. Your protagonist (Meetra Surik) without spoiling is so many different things to so many different people. Last Jedi, murderer, penitent war criminal, legendary military leader, traumatized veteran, heroic savior, evil witch etc. Any way you play her feels valid whereas KOTOR 1 pushed you to be either Jesus Christ or an absolute black hole of an ass for no real reason. I love how this game shows how even trying to do these best thing can result in untold amounts of suffering and sometimes there is no perfect solution to a doomed situation. She feels way more human than Revan who felt very overpowered and author insertish at times with no real tangible personality traits. Meetra has so much more to say and so much more to say it about. I highly recommend

149911125.review:
If you liked the refreshing and challenging ideas teased and attempted in The Last Jedi, but wish they had been more fully-realized, rather than absolutely squandered, then this is the game for you. It questions and critiques age-old tropes of the series like the hypocrisy and fallibility of the Jedi and the very fabric of the Force itself. 

Though it may sound counter-intuitive, the secret to this game's genius is the fact that it was written by legendary games writer Chris Avellone (Planescaper- Torment, Fallout: New Vegas), who, when tasked with writing KOTOR II, was admittedly not a huge fan of the IP. There's been a lot of this happening lately where Hollywood hires people who clearly have disdain for the very franchise they've been tapped to helm, with disastrous results. In Avellone's case, however, his outsider perspecctive, mixed with some very serious research into every piece of Star Wars media under the sun, and (surprise) his writing ability all lent themselves to making this one of the greatest, most simultaneously critical and loving Star Wars stories ever told, which is certainly in the top tier of the EU and wipes the floor with anything released since Lucas sold the property. 

If you ever dreamt of there being a successful and mature deconstruction of Star Wars that did so without showing any hatred or mockery for its own audience, but instead a great amount of faith in them to follow along and grasp themes far darker and more complex than any of the films, including thoise by Lucas, well, what are you waiting for? Ignore the fact that this was notoriously released unfinished, which was once a major issue but no longer. Simply grab the Restored Content mod/patch (which doesn't restore everything originally envisioned, but as much as possible) and enjoy one of the best RPGs and definitely the best Star Wars RPG ever made.

148524787.review:
Probably my favorite game EVER. This game, despite its age, still holds up better than most modern single-player story games. I prefer it over the new Jedi games, (although I haven't played survivor), and it proves exactly why the old republic is so much more interesting than the Skywalker Saga era. 

SPOILERS!!: While it is much shorter and obviously rushed out the door, this game honestly beats out the first in every aspect for me, those being: the villains, planet progression, characters, story twists. I feel as if I had a lot more control in this game, allowing me to build my play style a lot easier. Some critiques I have are obviously going to be the movement and camera control, something that is honestly atrocious to experience, as well as certain progression bugs, but it overall runs extremely smoothly and fluidly. 

Nihilus has to be my favorite Star Wars character behind Maul and Galen Marek, and his ability to consume planets is so badass, as well as the fact that hes a literal wound in the force. Treya is a close fourth, as she's such a backstabber and you never REALLY expect things from her until the end, as throughout the game she's much more of a grey Jedi teacher. The ability to go total darkside and have your character on the main menu, replacing the previous sith lords is a nice touch. too. 

I love the planet progression, and the interaction with certain characters, as this series overall has incredible world design and dialogue, with some of it being the most quotable pieces of fiction out there. Without giving TOO much away, my favorite planet and part of this game has to either be Malachor V or Korriban, two planets modern canon has increasingly forgotten, (instead we get Crait). All of the planets are great, and the ability to gain prestige with Mandalorians as well as explore the criminal side of Na Shaddaa make this game an amazing experience.

148421519.review:
I think it's safe to say, that while childhood nostalgia plays a big part of my love for this game, it still holds up as a solid RPG, and as a part of the Star Wars universe, it is truly the black sheep of the franchise.

Now while this game is a sequel to Knights of the Old Republic, I should note that you don't really need to play the first game to wrap your head around what's going on and often you'll have characters explain past events to help you catch up (Trust me, you can have a drinking game about the number of times people mention either Revan, the Jedi Civil War or the Mandolorian Wars) though some elements may not have the same impact without at least a passing knowledge of the first game. The story itself is a hefty deconstruction of not just Star Wars, but RPGs as a whole, providing some interesting commentary through jaded lenses, which is a sharp contrast to the first game which is good old fashioned Star Wars fun.
As for the game's characters, I'll confess I found them to be a mixed bag, some I found interesting in one way or another... and then you had others who could've been cut from the story and you'd lose little content, and lastly I will admit while I did enjoy the story, there are still a few sticking points that I'm not sure would've been solved by giving Obsidian more time to polish the game.

So how's the gameplay? It runs on a D20 style system like the first Kotor and the Baldur's Gate Series, and is one aspect of the game that is a major step up in comparison to the first, with such benefits like a higher level cap, more powers and feats and an expanded upgrade system (That really lets you turn your whole party into a force a nature), and starting as a Jedi is also a nice plus, I do admit I couldn't help but laugh at times do to how OP I got, and the rest of the party were nothing to sneeze at either. However I must make mention that both the beginning and the end of the game (In my mind at least) do have some issues. For the beginning of the game, it just kinda drags a bit, I don't think its awful but things kick into high gear once you can travel to different planets on a whim. As for the final level, there isn't too much beyond fighting some really tough enemies (Which made me really grateful that I was so powerful, cause even a simple mistake on your part can kill you)

Despite my nitpicks, the game has been a blast to play (And the restored content mod on the workshop is like extra frosting on the cake) and to be honest, I'd even recommend this game (along with Kotor I) to someone who isn't a Star Wars fan. Because it's a good game, period.

The only things I didn't like are small little nitpicks I have, nothing that ruins the game for me. The boss battles were challenging, but not so hard that I would rage quit. The story is intriguing, and nicely tells us what happens to Revan, if you listen.

147335329.review:
Released in 2004, STAR WARS™ Knights of the Old Republic™ II - The Sith Lords™ (KOTOR II) is the highly anticipated sequel to the original KOTOR. Developed by Obsidian Entertainment and published by LucasArts, this game delves deeper into the moral complexities of the STAR WARS universe while refining the gameplay mechanics of its predecessor. As someone who has journeyed through this dark and philosophical RPG multiple times over the years, I'm excited to share my detailed review of KOTOR II.

Gameplay (9/10):
KOTOR II maintains the exceptional gameplay of its predecessor while introducing subtle improvements. Combat feels more refined, and the addition of new Force powers and character classes expands gameplay possibilities. The game also introduces the influential "Influence" system, allowing your choices to influence your companions and their abilities. However, some fans might find the combat slightly unbalanced at times, particularly in the late game.

Character Development (10/10):
Character development is at the heart of KOTOR II's brilliance. The game introduces a deeper exploration of morality, with morally ambiguous choices and characters who challenge traditional notions of good and evil in the STAR WARS universe. Kreia, the enigmatic mentor, stands out as one of the most complex and thought-provoking characters in video game history. The character-driven storytelling and the influence of your choices on your companions' fates make for a compelling narrative.

Storytelling (9/10):
KOTOR II's story is a dark and philosophical exploration of the consequences of war, betrayal, and the nature of the Force. The game presents a morally grey universe where Jedi and Sith alike grapple with their beliefs and choices. The narrative is rich in detail and world-building, though it suffers somewhat from pacing issues and an incomplete ending due to time constraints during development. Fortunately, modding communities have filled in the gaps, providing players with a more satisfying conclusion.

Graphics and Sound (8/10):
The graphics in KOTOR II, like its predecessor, may not stand up to modern standards, but the art direction, character design, and world-building are still impressive. The game benefits from the iconic STAR WARS soundtrack, creating a familiar atmosphere for fans of the franchise.

KOTOR II, while not as commercially successful as the original, left an indelible mark on the RPG genre. It continued the legacy of player choice and moral ambiguity in storytelling, further solidifying the influence of the first game. The deep philosophical themes explored in KOTOR II have sparked numerous discussions and analyses, elevating the game to cult status among fans of philosophical narratives in gaming.

My experiences with KOTOR II have been marked by its thought-provoking narrative and complex characters. The philosophical depth of the story has led me to ponder the moral dilemmas presented in the game long after I've finished playing. Despite its issues, KOTOR II remains a game that challenges players to think deeply about the nature of the STAR WARS universe and the choices we make in it.

STAR WARS™ Knights of the Old Republic™ II - The Sith Lords™ is a dark and philosophical masterpiece that builds upon the foundation of its predecessor. Its exploration of moral ambiguity and complex character development make it a must-play for any fan of the STAR WARS universe and RPG enthusiasts seeking a deeper, more contemplative experience. Despite its imperfections, KOTOR II's enduring impact on gaming and its ability to provoke thought make it a timeless classic in its own right.

This, alongside SWKoToR 1, stands as one of the best RPG's I've ever played. It has definitely aged, but it's aged gracefully, and playing it now is just as fun as when it first released. The gameplay borrows inspiration from DnD, not so much to feel like copying, but enough to give it that table-topy feel that modern games struggle to emulate.

Excellent narrative, meaningful and diverse combat and utility builds, interesting and compelling party members, and honestly this game has the absolute coolest representations of the dark side of the force of any star wars media I've seen. It may need a little tinkering to work properly on newer systems (I remember having to muck with one of the config files to get Widescreen to work properly) but man oh man is it worth it.

Uno de los mejores juegos del viejo canon de Star Wars. Para ser un juego del 2005 funciona bien en Windows 11, cosa que no se puede decir del primer Kotor. Tiene soporte del Workshop y con el TSLRCM la experiencia se hace mucho mas amena, agregando contenido que fue recortado por falta de tiempo.

Tengo la teoría de que el escritor (el escritor del Kotor 1, por cierto) odiaba a la gente de Obsidian o nunca jugo el segundo juego, porque la caracterización de nuestro personaje del Kotor 2 es horrenda.
La continuación de esta historia, a una escala mas global, se encuentra en SWTOR. Que, si bien es un mmorpg, esta mas enfocado al single player y tiene algunas historias interesantes.

145706421.review:
A "Must-play" classic of the genre

For anyone who is a fan of western style RPG's or the Star Wars universe at large I can not recommend a game more highly. Unlike a lot of other media in the IP, KotoR 2 delves deeper in to a very human take on the universe with a lot of moral grey rather than pure good and evil. (Though playing as either is still possible if you want that experience).

Set a handful of years after the previous entry in the series and 200 years prior to the MMO, the story is set in a galaxy reeling from a war that left the Republic crippled and the Jedi all but extinct. As "The Exile" your return into known space has not gone unnoticed by those who would hunt your kind. Throughout your journey you have the opportunity to pick up a fairly sizeable cast of companions each with hours of nuanced dialogue and quests that let you learn about their past and help shape their future in a very organic way that still holds up two decades later. Gone are the "Good vs Bad" arguments and in come deep questions about morality, what it means to be alive and how one exists in a galaxy where "The Force" pushes and pulls on us all.

The story itself is simple to follow and chocked full of memorable and impact-full moments, its character perspectives add a level to Star Wars that I personally haven't seen before or since and the sheer amount of things to do in the game never leave me short of options.

I originally played this on the Xbox when it launched but since coming to PC the game is full of new life. Addressing the elephant in the room, yes you 100% should play with the restored content mod as the original release was pushed out on a short deadline but the quality is there with or without the mods (studio approved) restorations. For those who have played Fallout 3 and then New Vegas, you will be familiar with the magic Obsidian can pull off when given an existing work to flesh out.

The combat is entertaining and based off of the D&D stats system and plays out in real time turns with a pause option. This can be something that takes a little getting used to if you don't play these type of games but takes only a small amount of learning. The pace of the game and plethora of tool tips (which can be turned off if wanted on additional runs or reset if you took a break) mean that your never blindly dropped into a situation you cant handle unless you went out of your way to speed run to dangerous places with no level ups.

I could go on for hours about the game but its still active fan-base, piles of novels based on its work and the YouTube content still being made today so far more than I can in this already lengthy review.

Pick it up if your a fan of RPG's, D&D inspired combat/stories and the Star Wars universe's more human and grey areas

I played KOTOR 1 - save Zaalbar's planet, save everyone on starter mission (100%), become a Sith Warrior, defeat Malak, dont betray the Jedi, and at the end I one-shot Malak. I played KOTOR 2 - with my 200 hour Kotor 1 save, which was uploaded from another steam account, and took 1 month to transfer through Steam Support. I woke up someone else, with Revan in the Kolto tank.

Best way to play KOTOR 2 - without kotor 1 save on normal and insane, then mods for normal and insane. Then after you 100% KOTOR 1, with a game save from KOTOR 1 you play KOTOR 2 with that save without mods, and then with mods on normal. :) SPECTACULAR!!!

144907341.review:
With TSLRCM, I firmly believe this to be the second best piece of media in the entire franchise - beaten only by The Empire Strikes Back. Even without the mod, when I was on XBOX, it ties with Fallout: New Vegas as my favorite video game of all time, and it has held that top position even before New Vegas pushed its way into that slot some thirteen years ago.

The writing is out of this world, the pacing and atmosphere remind me of some noir films from the seventies, the mechanics and gameplay are fun, the amount of choice and character-building is fantastic, the worlds feel alive, the characters feel alive, you feel alive. These things are especially enhanced when you explore the finer aspects of modding. I recommend against using the mod loaders from Steam and the Nexus, and instead performing installs manually or with the TSL Patcher. For those who are just starting out, use this guide: https://www.reddit.com/r/kotor/comments/145qaz7/kotor_1_2_mod_builds_fully_compatible_modular_mod/

144526358.review:
This is my favorite game out of the KOTOR duology (or trilogy if you consider TOR) but I have an unnusual relationship with this game, I love it and I hate it. It's almost a masterpiece but falls short of being one and here's why: It's not finished and never will be.

Years ago I bought KOTOR I on a sale and had a blast playing, then I bought KOTOR II because I craved more of it even tought I don't care about the Star Wars universe. What's special about Star Wars is not it's setting but the story told trough it's medium, some of the best have been told with the Star Wars universe as a backdrop.

I played this game for 50 hours until one of the very last missions on Korriban, the Sith academy planet, then my game fucked itself and my companions and other NPCS simply refused to advance me through the story. I've searched for a fix but the only answer I got in the forums was to reload a save so far in the beginning that I might as well start the game over. And so I did. 

After reinstalling the game and making sure none of the mods were conflicting with each other (I will talk about mods in the end, but they are essential), I powered through another 50 hours of the same missions I had just  done just to experience the ending of the story and the conclusion of my companions arc. And guess what? The bug repeated itself. At that pont I closed the game and never experienced the ending. 

And then you wonder  why would anyone recommend this game even tough they had this bad of a experience? Well, you see, I've played KOTOR I from the beginning to the end but I have never finished KOTOR II and yet, KOTOR II is the one I keep renembering, especially its companions. As I've said the strenght of SW in the universe itself but the stories told throught its medium and this game has one of the best stories and some of the best characters you will get to know in a videogame ever. I will not spoil much of it but Obsidian managed to create a memorable cast of characters, both new and returning from the previous game, and with it crafted a truly fascinating journey that revolves around defeating a powerful, menancing and seemingly undefeatable foe and dwelves into the morality of the Jedi, your morality as a Jedi exile and the internal conflicts of the people that accompany you in this mission. KOTOR is not just rough around the edges, it's an uncut gem that will never be chiselled into what it was supposed to be.

Mods are essential to this game, its unfinished state makes its almost unplayable without them. TSLRCM is essential but make sure not to get the Steam version, download and install manually as the Steam version can create problems for you.

144395975.review:
I would not recommend KOTOR II unless you really like old-style RPGs and have never tried this specific game.  It was great back in its day (I played through it several times off a CD copy when it came out, so ignore my hours played on Steam).  Today?  Play Star Wars The Old Republic (the MMO) instead - it's a better game, believe it or not (see last paragraph).

The gameplay is very dated.  Your character can either be a Jedi Guardian, Sentinel or Consular.  Think of them as representing physical combat, balanced combat, or Force-heavy combat.  Three advanced classes unlock later on - you can mix and match if you wish, but it's always good to select the direct upgrade of your basic class.

Combat uses an extremely simplistic RNG-based system with optional pause.  Select a target, select an attack, watch awkward attack animations until the target is dead, repeat.  As a Guardian you'll be spamming one single attack over and over the entire game (Power Strike, Flurry or Critical Strike) with the occasional Force power.  As a Consular you'll be spamming Force powers, but mostly the same ones (lightning etc.).  You can mess around with stealth if you want.  There's not much more to it.  Consumables exist, but aren't really needed on normal difficulty.  Playing on normal or below will be too easy for most modern gamers, as it's almost like an even more dumbed-down version of low-level MMORPG PVE gameplay.

There is an over-abundance of gear and the game suffers from "crowded inventory syndrome."  Most of it will be sold for money to buy some of the items that are actually good.  Crafting exists, but is relatively basic.  Make a few things, slot a few items.  That's about it.  Purely optional on lower difficulties.

There are opportunities to min-max your character build (crit-focus, maximize DPS etc.), but it's all fairly basic character building compared to modern games and isn't even remotely necessary on normal difficulty.

The game wishes you to follow a Light Side or Dark Side path via dialogue choices.  Unfortunately, this game was written before the prevalence of nuanced characters in video games.  With some exceptions, in dialogues your Light Side character will be a classic do-gooder and your Dark Side character will tend to be a mustache-twirling villain.  Help the old lady cross the road or kick her grocery bag for laughs - that sort of thing.  It *is* possible to play a sort of neutral character, but the game doesn't really care much if you do.

Your companions aren't badly-written (one or two are excellent - HK-47, for example), and it's neat to train some of them as Jedi or Sith.  They have decent back stories and plenty of opportunities to chat with them and gain influence points with them (they generally like or dislike your choices, sort of like Dragon Age Origins).  That's a big plus point for the game.

The planets you travel to are interesting and varied, and you deal with a nice selection of appropriate Star Wars scenarios.  There are memorable interactions with NPCs.  Another plus.

The game takes a long time to get going.  The prologue area is hours long and consists of navigating fairly linear hallways, opening the occasional container and slogging through numerous easy-peasy droid fights with a vibroblade or a blaster.  You won't have proper Jedi gear until you begin the 3rd area of the game, a good 5+ hours in.  The prologue is so notoriously dull that a mod exists to skip it, and most people who replay the game swear by it.

In short, good companions, interesting areas, varied and thematic quests, but boring and simplistic combat, very basic RPG systems, a slow start and a black-or-white morality system.  

The "sequel" MMORPG Star Wars the Old Republic is actually a better game in that it allows for you to be more than just a Jedi or Sith, and to play Light or Dark Side version of every character that is actually nuanced and interesting.  The Light Side Sith Warrior, for example, has scenes in which Jedi are confounded by your refusal to play along with stereotypes.  It's also quite possible to play single-player, and doesn't require you to grind or engage in the more tedious aspects of an MMO if you don't wish to.   Free, too.  I'd say play that and only resort to KOTOR II if you're desperate for something new.

144238809.review:
KOTOR II is a seriously underrated Star Wars game. I think this is for two main reasons: 1, it was largely overshadowed by the first KOTOR and other golden era Star Wars games, and 2, it's a fairly rushed, unfinished game. Yet despite all that it has going against it, KOTOR II manages to deliver a potent, engaging story about redemption, meaning, nuance, and friendship, in a way that feels unique and complex compared to the original.

To preface, I think it's almost necessary to play this game with mods. KOTOR II was notoriously rushed together in 16 months, leaving the game unfinished in some spots. The Sith Lords Restored Content Mod seeks to restore much of the cut content that resulted from the rush, and it makes the game much more playable. This and a suite of other mods were recommended in [url=https://www.reddit.com/r/kotor/wiki/kotor2modbuildspoilerfree/#wiki_ultimate_character_overhaul_patches]this Reddit thread[/url], which is what I used to mod my game. I'd highly recommend taking a look at it, since it made my playthrough 10x better.

KOTOR II serves largely as an addendum to the events of KOTOR, following a different protagonist as they reconnect with the Force after being exiled from the Jedi Order. It's a direct sequel to the events from the first game as well, taking place less than a decade after the Jedi Civil War. With a crew of misfits, including droids, smugglers, assassins, warriors, and former Jedi, you are tasked with saving the galaxy from an encroaching new Sith threat.

The Obsidian DNA can be seen very plainly in this game, as did BioWare's in the original. The companions and planets are all engaging, the weapon systems are complex and nuanced, characters all have an influence meter... to me, I can see how such systems went on to inspire games like Fallout: New Vegas or The Outer Worlds. While the story was cryptic at times, these core aspects of Obsidian's game design made KOTOR II a good game and held things together during its shakier moments.

Speaking of shaky moments... the end was just okay. While the rest of the game was a good time, everything from Dantooine onward was weak, especially when compared to the previous game. The story felt pretty incoherent, and I feel like they could've incorporated more story or companion elements. The penultimate stage is pretty much just a big temple full of enemies, which felt pretty anticlimactic personally. I feel that this was probably a result of the rush, and it's a shame that we weren't able to see a more conclusive, fitting ending. Regardless, though, I think it's still worth playing to the ending, if only to see how the great story up until this point concludes. Just don't expect much.

If you're an RPG fan, give this game a try. While it's not as earth-shattering as KOTOR might be, KOTOR II has enough tricks up its sleeve to keep you coming back for more, with an endearing cast and set of systems comprising the core of the game's success.

8/10

144232917.review:
[Note that everything I say here is contingent on the Restored Content Mod being installed. I'm not sure how many of my complaints would be addressed by removing it, but given the improvements I doubt they could ever be sufficient to make playing the game unpatched the preferable experience]

Some of the best character writing I've ever seen in a game alongside a very interesting story that puts the rest of the Star Wars franchise to shame for how much it meaningfully engages with the universe compared to anything else I've seen. Yet I can still only give it a 7/10 because of just how much its brought down by a mess of bugs and some godawful combat that did so much to sour the overall experience.

Kotor 1 was an alright game. The story and characters were generally good an I enjoyed my time with it enough to warrant a recommendation. The combat, while bad, was also unobtrusive and easy enough that I didn't need to worry about it all that much, instead sticking to the areas where the game was at its best.

Kotor 2 took both the strengths and weaknesses of the first game and amplified them both. The writing was a substantial improvement both in regards to the main plot (which makes this game my favorite piece of Star Wars media) and especially in the characters (with this game's cast being consistently great). But just as Kotor's strengths were made better, its flaws were made so much worse.

While the first game was buggy, it was never enough to outright hurt my experience. A few annoyances here and there but overall the glitches were of minimal importance. Kotor 2, by contrast, is a buggy mess than rendered the game nearly unplayable at multiple points and required me to close and reopen the game, adjust my settings, reload old saves, and more on dozens of occasions. And while I understand a lot of this is thanks to its very short development time, that doesn't make the final product any better to play.

But even more egregious for me was the combat. I didn't like Kotor 1's combat but it was simple and easy enough that I could get ignore it for the most part. This game (or perhaps just the Restored Content Mod?) made combat a far more integral part of the experience, ramping up the difficulty, adding far more encounters, and really forcing me to engage more deeply in what the system had to offer. Which would have been fine if the combat were actually enjoyable but that isn't the case. Its slow and boring, heavily reliant on RNG, poorly explained in-game, and wildly oscillates between painfully easy to frustratingly difficult. I legitimately had to cheat and turn on god mode in order to get through some sections because of the brick walls the game was expecting me to get past just while playing on Easy. Meanwhile I could get part the first game on Normal with barely any deaths outside of boss fights. I get the impression that the developers really enjoyed how the combat of the first game worked and wanted to give it a bigger role here, but for people like me who disliked the first game's combat their decision made Kotor 2 feel genuinely unplayable at points.

It really is a testament to the game's writing that I'm willing to put up with the gameplay and still recommend the game overall. If the story were on the same tier as the first game I would give this game a 2.5/10 and delete it from my computer at the first opportunity. But the game's stellar writing actually makes the game worth getting through.

143680070.review:
I've been a massive fan of Star Wars since I was a kid. And I've decided this is my favourite thing in Star Wars. I remember when I first played this I expected a cool and epic journey and boy did I get that. But what I didn't expect was a lesson in philosophy. This game goes places where the movies never did, asking unique and interesting questions about good and bad which seemed so black and white in the OT and where the prequels just scratched the surface. It elevates Star wars into something so much more then a space opera about a family. This is what I think Star Wars should be. It is such a unique story for Star Wars and as a result still feels like one of the freshest stories since the creation of the I.P even 20 odd years later. The only flaw I have with this game is that even though it preaches ideals which challenge both the light and dark and finding a balance between often times your character is forced to choose between the a simple good guy or bad guy option. Which seems some what strange in a game with ideals like this. But I suppose that may be a result of the time the company had to finish it. This left me frustrated at times. Because if you start to actually agree or believe with the ideals the games characters are trying to teach you then you have no real way to act on them. Which is quite annoying. Besides that I would recommend you download the restored content mod and buckle in to have your view on the Star Wars universe altered massively. Such an amazing game and story. 

Could not recommend a game more.

[quote=Kreia]La verdadera guerra se libra en el corazón de las cosas vivas, contra nuestra naturaleza, luz y oscuridad. Eso es lo que forma y une la galaxia, no las creaciones del hombre.[/quote]

A todo lo bueno que tenía el primer KOTOR (una excelente historia, un combate sólido y una soberbia representación del universo Star Wars), hay que sumarle unos compañeros bastante más adultos y complejos y, lo que para mí es el punto fuerte de este juego, la fuerza. Concretamente, me refiero a que se explica mejor que en ningún otro medio que yo haya visto/leído/jugado, todo lo relacionado con la fuerza, por medio de unas conversaciones profundas y con tintes metafísicos, que le plantean dudas al jugador.

En breve, KOTOR 2 es, a pesar de algunos bugs y de sus casi veinte años y todo lo que ello conlleva (gráficos y jugabilidad algo pasados), un sobresaliente RPG. Y si eres fan de Star Wars, es directamente obligatorio (porque probablemente sea el mejor juego de la saga).

Muy recomendado.

PD: funciona perfectamente en la Steam Deck.

142295592.review:
[h1] Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic II - A Stellar Game that Triumphs Amid Adversity [/h1]

Rating: ★★★★¾

Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic II (KOTOR II) is a remarkable game that showcases the resilience and creativity of its developers as they make the best of a challenging situation. With its compelling storytelling, complex characters, and deep exploration of moral ambiguity, KOTOR II deserves high praise and a well-deserved 4.9-star rating.

One of the standout features of KOTOR II is its engaging and thought-provoking storytelling. The game presents a morally gray narrative, delving into the consequences of war, the struggle for identity, and the complexities of the Force. The writing is sharp and introspective, challenging players to navigate the shades of gray within the Star Wars universe. KOTOR II's narrative depth offers a refreshing departure from the traditional Star Wars tropes, creating a more nuanced and mature experience.

The characters in KOTOR II are multi-dimensional and captivating, each with their own personal demons and philosophical dilemmas. From the enigmatic Kreia to the troubled Jedi Exile, the game explores the complexities of morality and the nature of power. The exceptional writing and voice acting breathe life into these characters, immersing players in their struggles and motivations. The character development is a highlight, as players are challenged to make choices that impact the growth and fate of the companions.

Despite facing development constraints and a rushed release, KOTOR II still manages to shine. The game's development team, led by Obsidian Entertainment, demonstrated remarkable resilience and creativity in delivering a satisfying experience. While some content was cut and the ending may feel abrupt, the game's dialogue options, companion interactions, and intricate world-building compensate for these shortcomings. The dedication of the developers in crafting a compelling narrative with limited resources is commendable.

Visually, KOTOR II showcases its age, but its art direction and iconic Star Wars aesthetics still leave a lasting impact. The environments, ranging from desolate planets to war-torn cities, are evocative and immersive. The sound design, including the iconic Star Wars soundtrack, adds to the atmosphere and reinforces the sense of being in the Star Wars universe.

In conclusion, Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic II is a great game that demonstrates the triumph of developers in the face of adversity. Its compelling storytelling, complex characters, and exploration of moral ambiguity set it apart. Despite the development limitations, the game's depth and creativity warrant a highly respectable 4.9-star rating. Whether you are a fan of Star Wars or RPGs, KOTOR II offers a unique and thought-provoking experience that should not be missed.

141947012.review:
Underneath the jank, sparse worlds where everyone has flat feet from permanently standing, PTSD stricken cantina enthusiasts, poor balancing and slog of a tutorial there's a really fun and engaging RPG that is still worth a replay every half a decade. 

The writing is clever, focusing on interpersonal interaction between the characters to elevate the game above more than the sum of its rushed (and now dated) parts and create the illusion of life and change on the ship. There was also an attempt to tie in the actual gameplay mechanics to the story, 

In terms of the combat, it is pretty simplistic and a little over reliant on random drops for materials and equipping multiple characters at once with decent gear. There are some builds that are so much better than the others that it makes repeatability less fun despite the obvious incentive to do so. The verbal jiu jitsu of dialogue combat can be more satisfying, long extended dialogue trees have never been better nor has reading all the choices before choosing an option. I'm also a little curious as to what happens when you cosplay as a sith lord with anti social personality disorder when youre still in your miners uniform swinging a vibrosword for 1-12 damage a turn.

Final and maybe most important thing to mention : tons of credit goes to the restored content mod, luckily there's a lot of randomly generated loot to sell for that credit. Does anyone want the clothing of a dead Jedi Master? I found it in a dying world filled with tangible pools of dark energy, the Sith blood will probably wash out of it. If Jedi aren't allowed to commit simony then I'm fucked.

140514626.review:
[h1]STAR WARS™ Knights of the Old Republic™ II - The Sith Lords™[/h1]
STAR WARS™ Knights of the Old Republic™ II - The Sith Lords™ is the second and final part of the KOTOR series. We move 5 years into the future and play here as a Jedi expelled from the order, who will decide the fate of the balance of power in the galaxy. The game was released definitely too soon, and it lacks some content, so I recommend installing a mod that restores it.
[h1]The Plot[/h1]
5 years into the future, and the Jedi Order has fallen, Revan has vanished, and the Republic is collapsing due to the attacks of the extremely powerful Sith. Our enemies here are the Sith Triumvirate using agents of the dark side as assassins. The trumvirate includes; Darth Sion, or the definition of a man too pissed off to die, Darth Nihilus, the Sith version of Marvel's Galactus, and Darth Traya, the ultimate traitor. I mention them because I personally think they are some of the most interesting Sith in the Star Wars universe. What is incredibly painful, however, is that the game doesn't give them much time to develop, they appear suddenly and disappear just as quickly. We start the game at the mining station, and it's a typical prologue, but I have a big problem here. To get out of this location and clear it 100%, I spent 2 hours there, and since the surroundings were boring to explore, by the end I had enough. At least we're already Jedi-trained, and even though we don't have a lightsaber, it's a bit of a relief. We meet our first companions here, and speaking of them, I personally think that they are not very interesting. Of course, compared to most games they are great, but compared to the previous game, it is a definite step backwards, not to mention our mentor in this game always has a problem with our actions, and although her philosophy is insanely interesting, but commenting and picking on everything I do is incredibly annoying. The locations we visit during our mission to stop the Sith are interesting, although definitely smaller, which is a big improvement. We can also visit familiar locations from the previous game. There's also a light side and dark side system here, and as we're more of a Gray Jedi, this has a greater impact on the world and our companions, who themselves will change with our decisions. Of course, at the end, we also have the option to side with the Jedi or the Sith. Personally, I think this game has a lesson in forgiveness, or are we to forgive the Jedi Masters who unjustly rejected us. Personally, these masters are so annoying that I executed an early Order 66 on them (it's worth mentioning that the events of this game itself, are during the events of the first Jedi Purge).
[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Mostly a big improvement over the first game. Lightsaber combat is much faster, there are more animations here and it looks much better overall. There is more interesting inventory and the maps are interesting and well structured. The character creator is better, we have better face choices, and there are a lot of new skills here so you can experiment more. And thank God that the character no longer gets stuck on literally everything around. It is also worth mentioning that the UI is much clearer and better for the eye. However, I feel like there's a step backwards in terms of side quests, a lot of them are typical "go there, talk to someone and get me something", which is really boring, but considering the game was released at an accelerated pace, then I understand that most of the interesting content was unfortunately cut out. You can see a lot of indicators in this game, that some things had not been finished, which is really annoying when some threads go nowhere.
[h1]Technical Matters[/h1]
A slight tragedy. Despite the improvement in the quality of the gameplay, good music, great work by the voice actors and improved quality of graphics and effects, the game has many annoying bugs. Some dialogues either activate too late, too quickly, or not at all, sometimes the voices and music cut off completely, and the game requires frequent restarts because of these bugs. There's a lot to list here, so I recommend installing a good mod from the workshop.
[h1]Summary[/h1]
A very good game, which unfortunately suffers from lack of content and technical problems. It's really a shame that the developers didn't get more time to finish this game, but even so, it's still one of the best Star Wars games that ties in nicely with the previous game. It was supposed to be a trilogy, but unfortunately it didn't work out, and the story of Revan and Jedi Exile is continued in SWTOR, and in the books (which I definitely recommend).
https://youtu.be/7Fl48HXJhSg

Look past the unrefined technical construction and antiquated visuals, and you'll find one of gaming's best stories: A cynical skewering of the Star Wars mythos and its ideals, with complex characters and distinct ideologies subject to your benign or malign influence as you determine a new ethos for the galaxy: Who does the Force really belong to? What is power without subjugation? Can failure and villainy really be redeemed?

[i]KOTOR 2[/i] tears down the many assumptions of the Star Wars brand, the stories that inspired it, and the stories that emerged from it, with their reassuringly clear heroes and villains, clear intentions, clear plots, and clear moral stances. By jettisoning those foundational concepts out the airlock, it subjects you not to the bland fence-sitting of stereotypical "morally grey" chaotic neutrality, but to a genuine and surprising interrogation of the values we hold dear in contemporary - and sometimes ancient - storytelling.

This approach has greater weight in a galaxy that, several years after its predecessor, is a traumatised place shattered by terrible interplanetary conflict, with much of the proceedings adopting a drastically darker, even sinister tone, stretching everywhere from the grimmer writing to the literally darkened UI. The starry-eyed optimism of Star Wars proper is long gone; here lies a civilisation entombed under the ashes of a catastrophic war that has poisoned its survivor's minds with exhaustion and desperation, with an uneasy respite from the carnage only serving to raise tensions and set the stakes even higher into an ominous feeling that the slightest push in either direction could send the whole galaxy tumbling into collapse.

It also goes beyond the usual boundaries of Star Wars themes to seriously examine difficult subjects reflecting the real world's troubles. Should the poor and weak be blindly helped? Is manipulation admissible if it steers its victims into resilience or ignorant safety? What should we do when hierarchies become obsolete? Does empathy have practical value unto itself? What is the role of institutions when the system they serve has fallen into chaos? These and other questions all, ultimately, relate to the central theme of power - and how it is given, taken, and used. [I]KOTOR 2[/I] doesn't hate Star Wars: It's inseparably embedded in its tropes and stories, and gleefully delivers all the lightsaber action and interplanetary antics one could dream of, but what makes it such an unorthodox game is its self-aware metatextual introspection. It's something of a gamified postmodernist debate on the powerful cultural concepts that make classic Star Wars so enduring, with Luke's innocent, longing gaze at Tatooine's binary sunset or Darth Vader's tragic redemption giving us comforting assurances of the nobility of adventure and certainty of love, painting perhaps an overly simplified picture of humanity that echoes our need for existential self-justification. If [I]KOTOR 1[/I] uncritically (albeit remarkably skilfully) regurgitates this optimistic paradigm, [I]KOTOR 2[/I] challenges it - but never neglecting its value, and should you desire, even indulging it, but now with greater definition and understanding. Your new player character can be just as optimistic and constructive as in [I]1[/I], but now you can delve so much deeper into the how and why, and determine the details in the fuzzy ideological plasticity that [I]2[/I] offers, both to flesh out roleplaying possibilities, and to deliver a more believable and textured story.

What's fascinating is the way these themes intersect with your player character. The admittedly tired trope of an amnesiac protagonist is used to great effect, repurposing what could have been a dull and impersonal blank slate into an opportunity to mold a new morality for yourself. Many games make the mistake of telling their story [I]at[/I] you, where your access to perfect information and total control over outcomes defines you as your own personal deus ex machina. Instead, there's now rarely a perfect solution to a problem; people will take advantage of you if you're not careful; you can't always save everyone; you'll have to make sacrifices; and often, there's simply no truly good outcome. You don't just show up, solve everyone's dilemmas, and leave as a hero; this is a galaxy that needs you, but now also suspects you, uses you, and pushes back. Crucially to the story, even the most helpess people are no longer quite so straightforwardly pliable, and much of [i]KOTOR 2[/i] is about debating your way into a position of power over those around you. The way you work within the confines of these limitations creates a vessel for subtle, philosophically expressive roleplaying in a way that binary moral choices or predictable writing never could. And these winding roads aren't a solo journey: Your companions react to your choices in complex ways, sometimes resisting them, sometimes supporting them, in some cases being so profoundly influenced by your actions that their world view may radically shift, changing their alignment and even their character class... Sometimes to shocking degrees. This flexibility in self-expression, and its accompanying reactivity from the uncertain world and its fluid characters - standing on the shoulders of fantastic writing - is extraordinary for its quality and rarity, and the main motivator for my replays every few years.

I've discussed the writing almost exclusively so far, but the gameplay is similarly strong, if a bit archaic by today's standards. You're of course going to be slicing aliens up with lightsabers and playing card games in space cantinas. There's all the combat, dialogue, puzzles, trade, and exploration you'd expect from any western RPG, wrapped up in the rusty and dusty pre-sequels Star Wars imagery. If you have zero interest in the complex moral dilemmas or what is effectively entertainment iconoclasm, then this remains a fantastic time, with the same enjoyable D&D-inspired mechanics and captivating worlds as [i]KOTOR 1[/i], and some particularly impactful music again. But really, this game's greatest strength is its dialogue, especially if you keep Kreia in your party, which is like enduring a 20-hour questioning from a caustic but caring mentor-philosopher, whose poking and prodding masks a powerful desire to deepen your understanding of the world and your place in it. The wider cast is brilliant, and each character is delicately written and deftly acted, but Kreia stands out as one of the most fascinating characters in any game, even after two decades, for her unrelenting pondering of Star Wars's philosophical conventions.

I passionately believe it's worth digging through some of the awkward presentation and unavoidable bugs to experience this sociological soul-searching, and all its delightfully Machiavellian twists and turns. If you take a deep breath and plunge into its murky waters, you might find yourself with a new perspective on the pop culture spearheaded by Star Wars, on the wider beliefs of our Western civilisation, and perhaps even on your own morality. What more could you want out of a cultural work than that?

[h1]★★★★☆[/h1]

139985745.review:
If someone asked me if this was the best star wars GAME, i would say no. But if the same person asked me it this was the best STAR WARS game, hell yeah. Gameplay wise both Kotor Games are severely lacking, with clunky combat, horribly unbalanced skills and a morality system that is very biased towards one side.

But on the other hand, this is THE best Star Wars story ever told, Kreia is by far the best written character in all of fiction and the atmosphere makes this the definitive Star Wars adventure. Most games that focus on the Story usually try to be as much as a movie, much to the dismay of those who see the full potential of interactive media to tell unique stories. Thankfully, Obsidian in 2005 shared this vision and uses the full potential, where every playthrough gives you more insight into the thoughts and philosophies of the characters.

As a game, Kotor 2 falls pretty flat, but as an interactive Story it is a true Masterpiece

139891953.review:
Here's another incredibly long recommendation from me :D

This game isn't just one of my favorite games of all time - It's also one of the best RPGs I've played and also the first western RPG I've laid eyes on. Lastly, I find it to be much, much, much, muuuch better than the original Knights of the Old Republic from BioWare. It takes the gameplay mechanics of its predecessor and improves upon them to a greater extent. There's no ridiculous level cap from the first game anymore either. Much more open freedom to build your character with the introduction of the Advanced Classes.
Lastly, the writing, story and characters are well-rounded and not drenched up in clichés like the first game. Knights of the Old Republic 2 throws the whole Light vs Dark concept into a bin and then dump it on the dark side of the moon.

In retrospect - The game basically views the Jedi & Sith from a broader perspective and then concludes "Hey, maybe they aren't so different after all". They both wear morning gowns for a living and carry wide coloured willie exstented swords as a means of defense or offense. Essentially, there is no good or evil in this game, just various shades of grey. This philosophy is something one would find in the game's characters, especially the enigmatic woman, Kreia. Most of the characters are incredibly complex, even the Han Solo-esque ones have a dark secret hiding in the closet.
There's no suave, secret, paragon of the universe response that will unlock their hidden feelings and open up to you. There's an interesting approval system, which I do consider a bit flawed but in terms of role-playing, it works. Once you've finally gotten to the heart of their character you'll unlock new abilities for the said characters. The best part: Even when you've gotten that far it still feels like you don't quite know everything there is to know about these characters.

I think it is best if I sum up the plot now -- The game takes place a few years after the events of the first game.

In classic Star Wars tradition, the Republic is on the verge of collapse alongside the Jedi... AGAIN. There are some tropes that Star Wars can never truly escape from I suppose. You play as an exiled Jedi... Knight? Master? Janitor? Whatever, the game is kinda vague about your previous ranking within the order - You've just returned to the known galaxy and thus missed out on the party of the first game -- I suppose this makes sense given that Star Wars doesn't seem to be restricted to one galaxy, but how the Exile have managed to NOT hear about the whole escapade in the first game is beyond me.. Guess she spent her time in a cave or a remote planet or something, ala Ben Kenobi. For some reason you find yourself onboard the ship of the Ebon Hawke, which people who've played the first game will recognize, and it has been badly damaged, explains a questionably-soothingly-female-voiced-sentient-AI as the tutorial begins.

You have the option of skipping this tutorial but it's probably best not to do it since it'll give you a better idea of what is going on and foreshadow danger to come. Not too long after your Exiled Jedi wakes up from her/his comatose sleep onboard an eerie space mining facility called Peragus. The whole place is mysteriously abandoned, and one of the only survivors seems to be an old woman named, Kreia. Like I mentioned she's an enigma and she seems to know a lot about you and the Force, so the next course of action is to figure out what has happened and get off the station. That pretty much sums up the beginning.

One of the other things I find that Kotor 2 does exceptionally well is that it allows the player to get easily integrated with the character of the Exile, despite her having an established background -- The well structured dialogue assignment paves way for role-playing a character who doesn't have a clue, as well as someone who's already familiar with the events of the first game. In addition to that - There's also the subtle choice of gender for the previous protagonist and selected occurences of the first game, without the use of an import system, in conversation with one of the characters. A smart way to build to connect both stories together as there'll be plenty of references.

So, I've talked a bit about what to expect from the characters, the story and gameplay -- Now I'd like to sum up some of the central themes. The game doesn't present itself as the "Save the world from the ancient evil" type of story. Instead, it sets itself up more as a personal story, about your protagonist and your followers. Every time you exit and enter your ship you'll usually find the party bantering with each other, alluding to a dark secret they are hiding or what have you. This is also brought to light in some of the story cutscenes, where Kreia will downright intimidate your crew by exposing their darkest secrets and have it consume them... Why? Because of The Exile. The Exile is unlike any Jedi or Sith and not because she drew the shortest stick, but because she did something in her past that none other could have done. Something that litterally draws the followers and Kreia alike, to the Exile, but one would have to play the game to understand. Most of the story is a lesson to the protagonist, and the player -- About the ideas of morality, and how being a nice & benevolent saint might not always be the right thing to do; Least of all being cruel and despicable.
Relying heavily on the Force is brought up as a sign of weakness, and that true strength comes from not needing it. All of this is dictated through the enemies you fight, the choices you make, the characters you meet and certainly through the character of Kreia. It's

KOTOR 2 is a story of self-realization, different shades of morality, confronting the past and learning from past mistakes to face the future. Knights of the Old Republic 2 gets a strong recommendation from me, simply for being unlike any other Star Wars game and with the Restoration Mod -- A much better game than BioWare's original Knights of the Old Republic! :)

138987866.review:
No spoilers.

Started playing this again recently after many, many years on numerous platforms (Xbox original first!)

Game play is fantastic, and the RPG elements are second to none. Choices have an impact in the wider story and there are genuine consequences, gambles that can fail or pay off. The companion arcs with light/dark are genuinely one of the best that exists, and you can follow stories of companions should you wish, treat them like absolute crap or use them as cannon fodder - it really doesn't stop you doing any of these things. You can be a god among men or the most backstabbing, selfish and deceitful Sith lord in the universe.

The story is basically loosely followed, and you can delve deeper into it if you so wish, or just plough through it and ignore it all - your choice.

Hundreds of side-quests, (maybe a slight exaggeration) all optional. Some are highly rewarding, some you get betrayed, others are worth nothing.  Side quests can also affect the wider story and side stories.

They really need to remake this game with new tech - nothing about the core game needs to change, except maybe restoring the cut content and general improvements/fixes done through mods.

I don't think it really matters if you are a SW fan or not - I know a few people that loved this and didn't follow SW in any capacity, so there is that element of it, too.

I really hope this gets a remake. In modern tech this game would be incredible.

10/10

[b]The bad:[/b]first, In this game they forgot Revan existed and instead of making him the protagonist (which would make sense) they just invent an excuse to send him far away and leave all of his companions behind,  the exile is very interesting don't get me wrong, but the characters and relationships that you worked so hard to create in the first game just go into the trash.
Second, the final part of the game is bad, you don't even care about some of the villains because even at the end you know virtually nothing about them, it felt rushed the whole final part, to a point where I was left scratching my head like: "What just happened? Why?" but you kind of followed along the events that transcurred until the final planet, that's where things go really bad. You go into a rushed fight against the main villain and you're told very quickly the future of your companions (which by the way you don't see most of them in the final mission, which is incredibly stupid) and the villain dies, you get told that you must go to deep space to find Revan and Stop the true sith and you don't get to say yes, no or whatever, and the only thing you see is the Ebon Hawk departing the planet and the credits roll. No final goodbyes to your companions, no talk, no nothing, it felt like the developers finished the ending in the last hour before publishing the game, very rushed. But despite the final section, I recommend buying it, it's worth it.

138921162.review:
Sinceramente, que decepción de juego, lo he cerrado antes de terminarlo. No entiendo como tiene tan buenas valoraciones. Vayamos por partes:
- Este juego lo hizo Obsidian en vez de Bioware, con muchas prisas y sin tanta experiencia en este tipo de juegos. Se nota MUCHÍSIMO.
- Está plagado de bugs por todas partes.
- El diseño de niveles es HORRIBLE. Los caminos se dividen en tantísimos otros caminos que te terminas estresando vivo. No tienen alma los mapas, se sienten... mal hechos.
- Los personajes, en su gran mayoría, son innecesarios y vacíos. Si no te quieren matar se quieren unir a ti, y a veces se unen porqué sí, sin sentido alguno con la historia.
- Lo de Kreia es para darle de comer a parte.
- Las misiones parecen sacadas de un MMO. En serio, que puñetero coñazo. Los textos y diálogos son exasperantes. Nunca sabes lo que estás haciendo, vas como un pollo sin cabeza, rezando que hayas cumplido el objetivo de la misión, yendo de arriba a abajo todo el rato.

Ahora vayamos al problema real. A partir de aquí [b]HAY SPOILERS. CUIDADO[/b].
Me paso todo el juego sufriendo, porqué el primero me encantó y quería darle una oportunidad a este. Todo el juego ha sido una tortura tras otra, confiando en que el siguiente nivel fuera mejor. He seguido jugando solo para saber más de la historia, para poder entender que es lo que ocurre conmigo, Kreia y el consejo Jedi. Mi idea era llevar un personaje algo rebelde, neutral. Sin ser del lado oscuro, pero tampoco muy amigo de la idea Jedi, pero siendo del lado de la luz. Por el momento parecía funcionar, el juego te da esa opción en todo momento. Ahora bien, en una misión me pongo del lado de unos rebeldes que quieren independizarse de la república, el juego ME OBLIGA a matar a un Jedi, y de pronto soy Sith porqué sí. De la nada, los otros Jedi que he encontrado, me quieren matar, soy malo maloso. Kreia me dice que he seguido el lado oscuro, que bla bla bla. De la puta nada, me he ido al lado oscuro, cuando estaba yendo por el camino de la luz. Tengo que matar a todos los Jedi que seguían vivos PORQUÉ SÍ. Lo siguiente que veo, es que el juego me obliga a matar a Atria como la Doncella y ahí ya, ha sido demasiado. He cerrado el juego, y a tomar por culo.

Bioware [b]era[/b] un titán de este tipo de RPGs. Darle ese trabajo a Obsidian fue un error garrafal. El modelo de juego que pretendían hacer, ha salido horrible, pero horrible de verdad. Yo no entiendo las valoraciones que tiene este juego. Es posiblemente de los peores juegos que he jugado en los últimos años. Ya ni siquiera me importa el final; si me lo termino pasando, será con mods para ser inmortal y tener algo de clousure.

138624935.review:
NOTE: This is a review of the Restored Content version of the game, which to be frank, is the only version that everyone should play. There's not ifs and buts to this, the "vanilla" version is just unfinished, plain and simple.

Sometimes I replay Kotor 1 because it has that fun "A New Hope" sense of Stars War adventure and silly tropey stuff, and one of the plot twists totally recontextualises almost everything on repeat playthroughs, but it's not super deep.

With Kotor 2 I just keep discovering these little tidbits that make me go "dang, how did I not notice this before" because the writing structure is just completely different. 

It's all thematic and character focused as opposed to plot-driven, but the plot is still very complex and consists pretty much of nothing but galactic power players stacking gambit on top of gambit, all of them revolving around *you*, the player, and what your character has done nigh-on a decade ago. It's very much a "personal epic" — the plot events are massive, galaxy-defining, and yet none if it matters as much as your own journey of self-discovery, a journey of coming to terms with your past, your past deeds, and the main hurdle to overcome here is whether or not you can live with yourself, with what you've done, and who you are.

Granted it kind of doomed the game from a popularity perspective because it was all so ambitious and uncompromising — and that, in part, alongside LucasArts meddling, pretty much made it inevitable that the project will never rise above a "cult classic" status. A real "what could have been" type situation, but in the end KotOR 2 being a beautiful, flawed gem of a game ended up killing the idea of KotOR the series. In a way, it's appropriate.

Admittedly putting the pieces of the plot together and figuring out character motivations can be frustrating and confusing, and the limited development cycle and the budget allocated to this game meant that a lot of the more ambitious plot and character hooks end up being presented in a very undynamic form, especially compared to KotOR 1. However I found that in a way it contributed to the overall feeling of isolation and alienation that permeates the game: your character cut themself off from everything that binds them to the world in an effort to avoid hurting others, and being hurt again.

The light side run is in the end, a story about overcoming trauma and learning how to open up to others.

One of the nifty ways Obsidian managed to write bits of Star Wars lore into that theme and use it for plot purposes, is how the Jedi Council in their reclusive dogmatism, lost their connection with their humanity.

The Jedi Exile is the most "human" of these Jedi because they were compelled to join the war effort because they could not stand idly by while others suffer.

And the simple ability to build camaraderie with their troops, other beings, and connect with them on a personal level, presented by the lore explanation of "force bonds", was what caused them to break during the pivotal battle of the Mandalorian wars — the experience of feeling every single life being extinguished there, especially those with whom they served, whose lives they held in the palm of their hand as their leader — someone they looked up to.

However that is just a nifty nerdy lore way of writing a character in terms of what you need for the plot.

Thematically however, it's just a representation of how any real person would feel after witnessing, participating in, or surviving an atrocity. Or tragedy. Or personal loss. Trauma. Getting into a fight where you get badly injured, surviving a car crash, getting bullied as a kid. Being alienated because of who you are, because of something you have no control over. The Exile is all that rolled into one package, and them being a war veteran that went through some of the most horrific battles of said war is just a compelling plot hook.

Probably one of the best "blank slate" protagonists ever created for an RPG, and one of the most cleverly-written protagonists in RPG history.

This game blew my mind when I was twelve years old and I barely understood it at the time, but it *felt* different to any other game I've played, and it still managed to resonate with me on an emotional level. Revisiting it now as a grown adult made that connection even more personal and deep. It is a sad, melancholy game exploring sad, melancholy themes, with quite a few of them hitting at times uncomfortably close to home, and it's not something many would expect from a Star Wars game of all things — but if anything it makes it that much more impressive that the writers of this game found a way to work with a setting defined by its Light/Dark dichotomy, and make it feel *complex* and real.

It's janky, outdated, the gameplay is simplistic, the AI is braindead, and overall the game's bugged to all hell. But this game conquered a chunk of my heart and called it home. Playing it was like reading a novel.

It may require one to reside in a particular mental place during a particular period of their lives to really feel connected to this game, and if you are, then I am sorry that you have been forced to go through that kind of thing. That said, trust me: it gets better. If nothing else, one can always carry on and see what's next in store, if only out of morbid curiosity.

"When one endures, it gives hope to others — and themselves."

— Jedi Exile.

137825040.review:
As a life long Star Wars fan, I've consumed many contents through my life from it's movies to comics and all the way to its games. Knights of the Old Republic series has one of the best Star Wars stories that I've ever encountered. The mystic vibe of the game, the story, twists, characters and its RPG elements is still one of the best till this day. And I can confidently say that it still is one of the best RPG game I've ever enountered.

You get to see the old stories and arcs in Star Wars which I'd wish were seen as canon. Even though you get to read a lot of stuff throughout the game, as a person who spent 80 hours on this, I can easily say that I never got bored of getting new information about the universe. 

This game not only adds to the Star Wars universe but it expends and emphasizes the meaning to many stuff that we've see in the movies. You even change your perspective to the planets that you know and their original residents. For example after this series I've grown very deep feelings for the Sand People and their history. I used to see them as raiders but now I kind of see their point of view. Only The Book of Boba Fett has reached this perspective after KOTOR.

It might not give you the best gameplay since it's turn based but given that it's made in 2004 I can say it's acceptable. And especially for KOTOR 2 they've fixed that "losing save" issue. So it's much better. I hope in the future we get to see a rightful remake for this amazing series and that we can experience the true form of Star Wars that many fans have been wanting to see for years. 
Until then, may the force be with you all.

137477812.review:
There are several well known sad “oh what if they had more time” stories in video game development, where it’s well known that the game was launched in a state that was viewed by its own developers as incomplete. Not necessarily even buggy or full of issues, but not containing everything that has been already prepared and shipped, but locked and normally inaccessible. And to me, Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic II: The Sith Lords is the saddest example of them all. The first title of Obsidian Entertainment, a gathering of incredibly talented and experienced people from Black Isle Studios backed by new no less talented team members, it remains my personal favorite Star Wars story of them all. No really – there’s not a single other piece of SW-related media that is as good as this. Yet, even with a fantastic The Sith Lords Restored Content Modification (TSLRCM for short) that restores a lot of cut content in its current 1.8.6 version, the game occasionally feels incomplete and playing the game can be a frustrating experience.

Set several years after the end of the first KotOR, this game tells a story that is far more nuanced than anything the first game had to offer and, really, anything the SW media usually has to offer, as it delves far deeper into the concept of the Force and philosophy of the Jedi or the Sith. It is no longer a black and white story of Good People fighting Big Evil. It’s more of an exploration of how The Galaxy Far Far Away lives with its constant connection to the unseen connecting energy that seems to decide the fates of people and influence their choices. And how this unexplained idea is weaponised by opposing world views, with no “right” or “wrong” answers available.

Due to this, unlike the first KotOR, it’s not just the global story setting that is excellent, with the details and characters suffering. Everything is interesting and exciting to learn more about. Every companion you can get (and one of them even depends on your Light or Dark side path) is memorable and interesting, with their influence on you and your influence on them isn’t just interesting, but an integral part of the story. This was also the game that established (or I suppose re-established if we count Black Isle) the love of this development team to give you long dialogues debating difficulty questions, being able to give the playable character a strong world view. And also to use skill checks everywhere applicable to give the choice in how you develop the character in the gamey RPG systems a place in the world, so it can influence the way your character acts and even be part of the story.

Though, what’s even more curious and not something I picked on in my previous playthroughs of the game, KotOR II very often gives important information to the players, without giving it to the player character. There are multiple moments, very smartly chosen and selected, where the players get to see cutscenes and dialogues that show important plot points and big twists, without the playable character being present and consciously aware of them. Almost as if implying that either those elements are being subconsciously felt by the main character, or giving the player a story role in the game as an agent of the Force, influencing the choices of characters. As your perceptions of things get influenced by what you know, what the character you control as does not. It seems intentional, as the game even justifies gameplay mechanics with the story in a very clever way

Whatever the intentions may be, the resulting story and the way its told is amazing and might easily be the strongest tale from Obsidian even to this day. But… it also might be the weakest gameplay experience of all their titles. The game can be very hard and depending on how you develop characters it can be even harder. There are moments, where it almost feels as if the title would want you to not get into the trap of “cleaning up the whole location” or “doing everything”, yet if you do play it “smart” you will be shooting yourself in the foot later, when you are forced into conflict and might find yourself underprepared. There are countless moments where your companions get to be the main character (even more in TSLRCM) and while they work fantastically story-wise, mechanically they often feel completely unbalanced. You have to smartly use every tool available to you, instead of just relying on attacks and normal offensive options, but even if you do, it might still not be enough to get through some areas without lowering the difficulty (which can be done at any point with no penalty) or save scumming your way through.

The game is in general more complicated in terms of gameplay, not just the story. Although, it is not always necessarily frustrating. A crafting system is introduced that expands the simple upgrade system from the first game. Interactions with companions also give or take away “influence” you have on them. Some skills are, actually, simplified instead – the implants are no longer tied to a skill, for example, and are now just dependent on the Constitution attribute. Mini-games are slightly reworked and the rather popular racing from the original game is now almost impossibly stupidly difficult for some reason. Multi-class as a concept returns, but is tweaked and an idea of prestige classes is introduced. Stuff still looks like it was straight up “borrowed” from DnD 3.5, but it mostly works just fine. Oh and what’s very different in terms of pacing is how many extremely long linear sections the game has in comparison to the first – after a very long linear intro section and apart from the non-less extended “end” section, even when you visit a planet you might get locked into a very long section which you cannot back out of.

Fortunately, the PC port of the game nowadays works pretty well after it has been updated in 2015. It has decent widescreen support that can be easily enhanced by the mods. Mods are easier to install, especially on Steam, where the game supports Steam Workshop. So I recommend the TSLRCM, widescreen UI fix and lightsaber colour fix whenever you decide to play the game yourself. Also you might look up how to correctly run the game in 60Hz mode as, unfortunately, just using a V-sync option might not help and the game breaks if your refresh rate is higher than that by not letting you move after exiting combat mode. Occasionally the game may also crash, though it’s relatively rare. And if you play the game for several hours suddenly all dialogues might start skipping without voices – restart the game to fix it. Sadly, no built-in fixes for these seem to exist right now. But the overall experience from the technical side of things is quite pleasant.

Whereas Knights of the Old Republic is still entertaining, but is otherwise almost entirely superseded by Mass Effect and Dragon Age, where BioWare revisited almost every good idea and made it better, Knights of the Old Republic II: The Sith Lords remains unique and unsurpassed. It’s a shame so much of its original intent is still lost or flawed in execution, even with the TSLRCM. And it’s a shame it can be a very frustrating game to play in terms of balance and general design missteps. But it’s a story unlike any other and I loved playing it again. If there could be a second chance or a remake given to a Star Wars game, this should be the one to get it, as even 19 years later KotOR II amazes and surprises. And I cannot recommend this game enough.

I never understood the acclaim for this game. I beat the first game on original Xbox around 15 times and it's one of my all-time favourite games. I then played through this and it was a buggy, incomplete mess. I'm not sure if it was something to do with how I play games but the story was almost incomprehensible. Characters were talking about events that hadn't transpired (or never transpired), and it was like I was being told a story completely out of order.

So after many years I thought I'd give them another go. The first game was amazing, the second... once again. Absolutely no idea what's going on. After beating it I read a recap, but I'm honestly not sure it's describing the same game I played. Perhaps you have to play the planets in a certain order for it to make sense, but I managed to get through the whole game with almost no idea what some of the villains were doing, and barely an idea of what the other was... but no idea why.

Some people have stated that it has a darker, more nuanced tone. But I felt like Jolee Bindo and Juhani combined had a more nuanced view of the force (sad), and saying the game had a more serious tone than the predecessors is silly, except for the corny maniacal villain of Malak. Regardless, I honestly could not even identify any dark or nuanced tone from this game. I spoke to all the NPC's, I listened to everything. It was a garbled mess.

I have not played with the restored content mod. I intend to do so, but out of the box... this is a painful experience if you have no nostalgic attachments to it. The gameplay does appear improved, but the story felt hollowed out compared to the original.

I mean, guess you can at least actually win at Pazaak without cheating...
