Negative and positive influence have the same effects so you don't have to worry about that. 136239099.review:
KoTOR 2 is, simply, the best Star Wars game ever produced.

The game works as an interesting essay in the more spiritual and ethereal dynamics of the Force as a supernatural resource, and discusses how the presence (and lack) of this would affect the inhabitants of a galaxy that hasn't known peace in quite a while. 

While it may feel that Chris Avellone really likes the metaphorical sound of his own voice, the writing on the game presents a level of deconstruction, parody and self-awareness about the overall narrative of Star Wars that you can't help but agree with the statements it presents the more you play and advance the myriad of plots the game has to offer. 

It's quirky, creative, interesting, but more importantly it's fun, as I consider this game to be the best simulation of living as a Star Wars character we've ever had.

Sure, games like JFO can show a better simulation of many singular aspects, like light saber combat or the frenetic fantasy action of a battle between force sensitives, but KoTOR sacrifices mechanics for layers and layers of abstraction that slowly form pictures in your mind's eye as if you were watching a masterfully crafted movie where the main role was written for you, specifically. 

And this is all just on the surface. If you've spent whole nights in SW forums, clicking random links on Wookiepedia and having sincere discussions about the current state of the franchise, this game will feel like a love letter for someone that loves Star Wars as deeply as you and just wanted to leave a grain in the beach that is the legacy of Star Wars, and this is not just about Avellone, but rather that had some involvement in this game. 

Whether it's about the main developers at Obsidian, the ones from Bioware that set the foundations, or the legions of fans that have made things like TSLCRM, M4-78 and other efforts to reconstruct the game's original vision, it's clear that everyone involved was tied by an ethereal chain that tied them together in their opinions, knowledge and love about the universe that is Star Wars. 

I don't know whether it was intentional or not, but the game's main theme (or at least one of them) about how the force connects us feels like a beautiful fit for everyone that has helped this game survive and still be able to be played and resonate by everyone that is willing to give it a chance.

This is truly a superb game, even as dated as it is compared to modern graphics etc. This game and KOTOR 1 are where it all began for two of Bioware's most beloved franchises: Mass Effect and Dragon Age. These games are where they refined the mechanics that would go on to be used in the later franchises. If you like how either of those play then would very much recommend the KOTOR games. 

I had previously only played the base version without the restored content, which is good in it's own right, but I thoroughly recommend the restored content mod (can be found in the workshop) to get the best experience of the game. I find that I keep coming back to this game and it's predecessor (KOTOR 1) rather than playing newer games, they were just built differently back when this game was made: In this game there's so much more emphasis on nuance rather than the tired old trope of good guy vs bad guy with no other depth or plot, the lines are far more blurred than that in this game. Some of the characters are superbly written and with the restored content mod we get to see even more of that depth to their characters. I thought there couldn't be a better twist/reveal than the one in KOTOR 1 but as the story in this game unfolds and the plot is revealed it really does come out of left field the first time you play it, even more so if you fully explore the dialogue options and get all of the background information that there is to offer. It is also apparent that different playthroughs offer different loot at times - I have found an armour suit that I have never seen on any of my previous playthroughs, which is a big plus in my books as it prevents the game going stale if you play it more than once.

All in all, this game is so good that I would encourage anyone to look past the dated graphics and slower turn based combat, because underneath that is an absolute gem of a game that is just as compelling now as it was then. Can't recommend it enough!

135518012.review:
Come, listen as I reveal the depths of her wisdom and the secrets that lie within her mind.

Once, in a galaxy plagued by turmoil and darkness, I found myself amidst a group of wayward souls, seeking to uncover the truth that lay shrouded beneath the veil of the Force. I, Kreia, a former Jedi Master turned teacher, had forsaken the Jedi Order, disillusioned by their flawed teachings and their blindness to the true nature of the Force.

Guided by my own unique perspective, I embarked on a journey with the exile, a Jedi cast aside and severed from the Force. Together, we traversed treacherous worlds, encountering allies and enemies alike. But our purpose was clear: to unravel the mysteries of the Sith Lords that plagued the galaxy.

With every step, I shared my wisdom, my doubts, and my vision of a galaxy liberated from the chains of the Force. I sought to enlighten my companions, to make them see beyond the superficial divisions of light and dark, Jedi and Sith. I challenged their beliefs, forcing them to confront their own inner demons and question the very nature of the Force that governed their lives.

Through our travels, we encountered various factions, each with their own agenda and hidden motivations. Mandalorians, Sith, Jedi, and even the droids that permeated the galaxy, all held a piece of the puzzle. With each encounter, I sought to peel back the layers, exposing the flaws and contradictions of their ideologies.

Yet, as we delved deeper into the secrets of the Sith Lords, I realized that darkness and light were not merely opposing forces, but two sides of the same coin. The Force, that eternal wellspring of power, was indifferent to morality. It was the choices we made, the intentions behind our actions that truly mattered.

In the end, the lines between Jedi and Sith blurred, as did the boundaries between my companions' loyalties. They were forced to make choices, not as pawns of destiny, but as individuals with the power to shape their own futures. And as they confronted their personal demons, I stood beside them, an advocate of free will and self-determination.

In the crucible of conflict, our understanding deepened. My vision of a galaxy liberated from the tyranny of the Force resonated with those who dared to listen. The teachings of the Jedi and Sith crumbled before the truth I offered, and the veil of illusion lifted, revealing the harmony that could exist beyond the dogmas that held the galaxy captive.

As the tale draws to a close, my companions and I stood united against the machinations of the Sith Lords. Our purpose, our journey, had shaped us all in profound ways. And in that pivotal moment, I knew that the teachings of Kreia, the renegade Jedi, would echo through the annals of history, forever challenging the notions of light and dark, and illuminating the path towards true understanding.

Thus concludes the story from the perspective of Kreia, a character steeped in wisdom and darkness, who sought to shatter the chains of the Force and guide her companions towards a new understanding. Remember, dear listener, that the Force is not bound by the definitions of Jedi and Sith, but rather by the choices we make and the truths we dare to uncover.

P.S. One of my favorite games!

135171135.review:
[i]Note: I played this game with the Restored Content Mod, something that might have affected my experience. Bear that in mind.[/i]

So, I think the first thing to note is that I’m in a clear minority here. KotOR 2 has a good reputation and I think I can see why. The shifting perspectives, the deep dives into lore and the discussions on morality are aspects of this game that you didn’t, and to some extent still don’t, see very much in games. With that said, I don’t think KotOR 2 succeeds very well in its aims. The development was troubled, and it shows; the game is messy and constrained, with mostly flat characters and a conflicted story. I will explain further what I mean below, but know that I played the first game before this, and the sequel feels so much older to play despite sharing a lot of the same DNA. If you want a TLDR, that would be it.

Lets begin at the beginning, because it’s pretty bad. You start as a Jedi on the run, with the Republic in shambles. Only five years have passed since the end of KotOR 1, and I say “only” because your victory in that game didn’t seem to matter for the galaxy at large. Already a bit of a blow, making your actions meaningless in hindsight, but it’s not a huge issue. What is an issue is the mining station you’re stuck on. Two words: Corridors and droids. For five hours or more you are stuck running down limited paths, pushing a few buttons and fighting a lot of the same droid through section after section. There is a plot point connected to it, but it’s weak when you consider that the cost is a tedious barrage of claustrophobic levels. On top of that, you only speak to a total of three (four if you count the R2-D2 clone) characters in the whole station. It’s the worst part of the game, and that this was the first impression they chose to give boggles my mind.

The next planet isn’t much better, but the game does gradually improve further down the runtime. With that said, the linearity and narrow levels does continue to be a problem pretty much throughout. I believe that it resulted from an attempt to solve a problem of KotOR 1, the fact that there was a lot of running back and forth between quest objectives; but instead of filling the empty space, they ended up shrinking the environments instead. They also leaned much too hard on combat encounters, with a lot of quests feeling like you’re just running from one group of enemies to another (often within eyesight of each other, breaking immersion in the process when they just stand around as you kill their friends). The shifts in perspective, where you end up controlling characters other than your main, are absolutely ruined by this, turning an interesting mechanic into a chore as you simply fight a bunch of goons without your biggest gun.

These problems also reveal other technical limitations. Pathing is the one area where I thought that KotOR 2 had really improved, it’s much smoother and your party members actually get out of the way when you want to walk past them. However, with how cramped the environments are, there are also more corners to get stuck on; and when fights are frequent, you might just suddenly realise that you’re missing someone. The targeting system is another part of this problem, as your party members automatically attack any enemy they can see if combat is initiated. This means that if another group is off in the distance but inactive, your party will run off to attack them. Thus, one fight might very well chain into several in a row, all while you’re constantly swearing at your supposed friends. To add to this, there is just a lot of jank: If a party member is wielding a long weapon, the tip of it will wave in front of your camera while walking around, which is fun. Cutscenes chain together if several different triggers happen at once, which happens several times and feels awkward every time, as you’re thrown from one event to the next. There is a truly delicious bug I ran into at the very end of the game, where dialogue started skipping because of a memory leak, causing me to miss crucial conversations. Again, this game feels [b]old[/b] and on top of installing all the mods to fix problems, I had to wrangle with this game far more than the first.

On the same theme, there is the influence system. In the game, you can gain or lose influence with your party members, replacing the conversations being unlocked by leveling up in KotOR 1 with topics that get unlocked by influence. Sounds great – if it wasn’t absolutely broken, that is. You can get influence with most characters by simply approaching and talking to them, so what happens is this: You approach a party member you just recruited, talk to them to know more about them and end up gaining enough influence to unlock one of locked topics. Then you go through that topic, and you get even more influence, enough to unlock the next one... [b]You can unlock every influence-based topic and max out your influence with most characters in one conversation[/b]. I don’t know if it was somehow intended, but it feels extremely artificial, like your party members are puppets with canned responses that only activate by the right sequence of voice commands. Did I mention that the characters are flat in this game?

Alright, maybe I should go into that a bit more, because I’m sure that a lot of people actually do like the characters. They are likable enough, I liked the way that they interact with each other and argue with you, dialogue is better than the first game and they all have involved backstories. The problem is, I know a lot [u]about[/u] these characters, but I don’t [i]know[/i] them. Their wants and needs for the future, their doubts and their guilt, what haunts them at night – nothing comes through. Instead, they’re dark side or light side bots, only challenging you to make you think about your alignment and never having the opportunity to be challenged themselves. They never go beyond the character concept to become people. This is something the first game did better for several of its characters and it got lost here. 

Maybe that is because this game is so focused around the main character, the Exile, and your alignment. The whole story seems to be centered around questioning the dark and light side divide, with several choices that are delightfully challenging where you have to start thinking about what is moral for you, not about what is light and dark. This and the deep and human discussions about the Force and how it and its users affect people are the best parts of the game, and they are great. Sadly, it’s not reflected in the gameplay, and it doesn’t last. You get huge stat bonuses if you go towards the extremes, making it still a game about choosing light or dark; there are no incentives for choosing a greyer path. The plot also loses its grounded quality in galaxy-shattering Force powers, doomsday weapons and cartoony villains. There are plot points that are never resolved or forgotten entirely, with contradictions and anticlimaxes as a result. As such, even the best part of the game is troubled, which didn’t help my overall impression of the game.

I see a lot of people say that KotOR 2 is a great game. But I’m sorry, I just don’t see the greatness. It’s not a terrible game, it’s fully playable and you might have fun with it, but there are so many games that are better than this. If you want to play some gaming history I would say go for it, though if you play the first one instead you actually get a great game on top. Otherwise, it’s just too mangled and messy for me to recommend in good conscience.

A more mature and darker take on Star Wars and its universe, which treats the player like an adult and poses to them philosophical questions about the existence of "The Force" and what that means on free will. I highly recommend this game, as it is probably my favorite overall piece of Star Wars media due to the questions and ideas it presents.

134175704.review:
I've played this game for so long and have never written a review for it. This game made my childhood and it got me into RPG-style games. I remember not knowing how to play it and all I wanted to do was swing my lightsaber around and fight bad guys lol 

(Coming from the creators of Fallout New Vegas, which is considered to be the best Fallout game of all time, you're in for a ride.) 

Then i got older and figured out you can basically become a god in this game if you choose your powers and equipment carefully or find powerful gear if the RNG lets you. As you may figure out, there's a limited amount of loot you can actually get. I miss these days of gaming where every item actually has a purpose and is usable instead of just being junk or "crafting materials" that you'll never use. This game revolutionized what crafting in an RPG can truly be. If you actually put points into Repair or Treat Injury, you'll be able to craft some of the best items in the game. Newer games should take a look at this one and realize that if you put well-seasoned writers and good caring developers into the mix, you'll be unstoppable. 

However, I loathe to see what this game might be if it was made in modern times. I imagine I'd see a battlepass or mountains of DLC that contain shitty costumes. It's simplistic and minimalist without losing any valuable luster. Most games these days have tons of numbers, colors, and text flashing on the screen bordering on satirical that does nothing but trigger sensory overload and just make the experience overall unenjoyable. Add the pleasant UI into the dark, cloudy ambience, delve-worthy dialogue and lore, interesting characters and plot lines, menacing villains (one of which is comparable to an eldritch horror), and fun combat and you got a game that deserves all the praise it gets. Granted it was rushed toward the end and the devs had to cut corners, but modders today finished their work and made the game all the more memorable. Not to mention this game took a turn from the cartoonish, diabolical villains and cutscenes and made into a game with lore and backstory as deep as the mariana trench and dialogue that brings about questioning of real life morals. 

ALSO: one last thing. The dialogue options are highly flexible according to the situation and allows you to place your own spin on the story depending on what you pick. You can go from a fallen jedi looking to revive the sith empire, an embarrassed exile looking to redeem their past sins, a beleaguered apprentice looking to get revenge on those who cast them out and cutting down sith, jedi, friend, foe, or whoever gets in their way, or a hesitant force-sensitive hero who is forced to pick up a lightsaber once again and fight an enemy that is worse than death itself. 

There are games. And there is art. And then there are games that are art. This is one of them.

134007658.review:
Despite the restored content mod being used upon my initial play through, the game was just too rushed to be salvaged by anything a fan could attempt to do. 

The game does excel in exploring a theme so nuanced, with such complexity in contrast to how black and white Star Wars story telling was at the time of release. Yet this theme is contradicted through game play by making the player choose either the "Good" or "Evil" choice in dialogue options.

As for gameplay, there is none. Combat is so dated, and it tries to be smarter than it really is. Just put your XP points into force lightning, and charisma, you'll end up destroying every fight and skill check the game has to offer. There's no reason to fill your party full of jedi other than the fact that a certain character will get locked into a 1v1 boss fight with a villain later in the game, and if you never touched them once, you'll be soft locked and unable to progress forward. In my case it was Atton, against Darth Sion. 

I could forgive the poor RPG elements, and poor gameplay, if the story at least had a worthwhile conclusion. Unfortunately the ending is just boring. Darth Nihilus is one of the biggest missed opportunities, and there's zero satisfaction in defeating a character that was built up as a massive threat, due to how little the game actually does with him. Sion ends up being a dialogue skill check boss fight, and Darth _____  just sequel baits in the final fight before the game abruptly ends

All of it's problems are even further exasperated by the fact that KOTOR III didn't even exist to capitalize on what II spent so long setting up. SWTOR and the EU novels attempted to provide some closure, but they clearly weren't what the original vision was, and Revan was given such a lackluster fate. 

KOTOR II is a disappointing sequel, both as an RPG and a story. Choices inevitably do not matter.

133899532.review:
KOTOR II, while seemingly outdated in terms of today's mechanics, and more rushed than it's previous installment, is still a very engaging and entertaining game. While the learning/difficulty curve may have it's drawbacks to playing the game itself, from finding the right abilities, weapons, and gear for the various combat encounters that can mean life or death in certain circumstances where you can find yourself overpowered by the enemy, thus still having the necessity for strategic thinking and problem-solving skills for various situations you'll find yourself in.

I'd say it's better than the first game [I've played KOTOR I on Xbox, not Steam] in the aspects of conveying a much more grayer, and morally nuanced narrative, with it's tone being more melancholic and emotionally pulling that puts a more unique spin in the Star Wars universe. The game has well-crafted settings, from it's diverse planets, unique cultures, the people and creatures you'll come across that shows one area isn't like the others as you explore, which can be appreciated by Star Wars fans.

One of the biggest strengths KOTOR II has is the large variety/freedom of choice you can have. A player can be a gun-toting smuggler like Han Solo, or a righteous Jedi such as the Skywalkers to put an example up. Your choices when interacting with your companions and the story as a whole do have an impact on how they are influenced by your decisions and what those consequences could be. 

Overall, if you've played other RPGs, this game is one I'll recommend you to play. I'll give it a 9.75/10 [-0.25 cause I didn't like that door puzzle in Nar Shaddaa]

TLDR: Game is very fun with a good story, would recommend playing.

KOTOR 2 gets 4.7/5. 

Despite its slightly outdated feel, the gameplay is engaging from beginning to end, which I can't say about a lot of games.

It's biggest weakness is its difficulty curve, as you can become quite overpowered with the right abilities and decisions, although strategic thinking and problem-solving skills are still required for most situations.

The game's biggest strength lies in the player's freedom to make choices that impact the story and its characters. There are stuff you can do that will make you go "OK so plot-armor isn't a thing in this game...".

The game world is well-crafted, with diverse planets known most to Star Wars fans, offering unique cultures, creatures, quests and challenges to explore.

The game's duration is more than fair, providing you with a lengthy campaign that took me 60 hours to complete first try.

I'm never a fan of complicated stories but the one in KOTOR2 is very well-written and well-paced and it even introduces new perspectives untouched to the vast Star Wars lore that I was a huge fan of so it was easy to like.

Overall, KOTOR 2 is highly recommended for RPG fans but it's a must-play for any Star Wars fan.

133479234.review:
KOTOR 2 is a worthy successor to KOTOR 1 even if it was left unfinished due to the publisher and deadlines. I know for some people this might not be a good sell, but to truly appreciate this game as the developers intended, I would recommend the Restored Content mod which as the name implies restores some of the content that was cut and also helps with patching the more serious bugs in the game. Highly recommended.

Besides the Restored Content, the gameplay is similar to the first with all its pros and cons that come with it but there are some improvements like the crafting system has been expanded for instance giving the player more options how they can customize their character and companions. The powers have been expanded upon as well that one gains as they play through the game which makes playing as say a Jedi Consular more interesting and fun. The game also introduces the Lightsaber & Force forms which like the powers and crafting gives the player more options on how they want to approach the combat in the game.

The companion system of the first game has been improved, giving the player 12 instead of 10 of the first game. Some companions are exclusive to certain alignments and genders (ex. Hanharr & Mira). There is a system in the game that lets the player gain or lose 'Influence' over a character which gives the player more options for their playthrough. For those who played the first game, some companions form the first game appear here but I'll let you find who those companions are.

Mark Griskey's soundtrack is fantastic, it keeps that Star Wars feeling that you all know and love but enhances it as it complements the game's dark undertones and conveys the appropriate mood for each scene.

Finally we get to the story/setting of KOTOR 2. The game is set about 5 years after the events of KOTOR 1, the Republic is at its worst point from the Mandalorian Wars and Jedi Civil Wars, the Sith are back but stronger than ever, and the Jedi are either dead or hiding. Very grim setting we have here, which goes well with the themes that the game explores which makes it unique from other Star Wars stories. Without gushing over it and giving spoilers, the game improves over the sequel in terms of the plot, setting, themes, and characters in the game. The game with its dark setting, memorable dialogue, carefully crafted plot, villains that outshine the first game's antagonist, memorable characters, and themes dealing with the Force and the Light/Dark side conflict. 

For those who played the first game, its not as well known but you can alter somewhat how the first game ended with your character without getting into spoilers like when you talk to a character named Atton in the first hour in the game, you guys talk about KOTOR 1 and the fate of your character. The only things you can change is if your character was either Male or Female and Light Side or Dark Side. Once you pick the options you want, your character in the first game would be referred to as the options you picked for the rest of KOTOR 2. Again this section is only for those who played KOTOR 1.

So, all in all, highly recommended, you won't regret it. I recommend that you play KOTOR 1, get the Restored Content mod for this game, and be immersed into one of the greatest if not possibly the greatest Star Wars story of all time.

133466200.review: This is, hands down, the greatest story in all of Star Wars. It's not the most adventurous, not the flashiest, and by far the darkest and least child friendly, but all in all, it's the most complete (Ironic wording, admittedly) and detailed tale about the darkside of not just the force, but life in a galaxy that has suffered over and over and over with no end in sight, and no way out. It's a suffocating story about finding personal strength through adversity. 10/10 story. The gameplay however does suffer a bit in how dated it is, but it's still fun, in my opinion.

133277433.review:
[h1]Brief Review of Knights of the Old Republic II: The Sith Lords[/h1]

[i]“5 years after the events of the award winning original, the Sith are on the verge of crushing the Old Republic. As a lone Jedi, will you follow the light side or succumb to the machinations of… The Walt Disney Company?”[/i] *cue Imperial March music*

Oops, I may not have gotten the above byline quite right. That was probably offsides. Let’s carry on with the game assessment…

[i]This review is not dedicated to wanton slaughter. Nor body count. Rather, it is about finesse, function. Doing more with less. It is dedicated to ‘art.’[/i]

[i]Secondary dedication: to the fourth proton core that never quite triggers for me.[/i]

Knights of the Old Republic II: The Sith Lords is a fantastic game. It is one of my favorite games along with the original.

What can I say? I love the setting, the characterizations, voice acting, galactic conflict, and universal themes—not to mention the lightsabers and Ithorians, man. It even includes a token Wookie (Leave Mira alone, you herculean fuzzball.)

For me, playing this game is like reading a favorite novella or comic book. Warts and all I truly enjoy the unfolding narrative. And the concept that a force user could become so unbelievably out of plumb as to threaten life on the scale depicted in the story is terrifying… [spoiler]Given the right circumstances, they have the potential to become wounds in the force; that is, walking black holes capable of wiping out life in the universe. Bruh, that ain’t good[/spoiler] well, no spoilers here, move along. Let’s just say that I can understand why the rank and file have difficulty differentiating between Jedi and Sith. The story makes a good case for hunting down all force users and their little dogs too…

And yet, this review would be remiss without mentioning the things that plague my playthroughs; that is, the galling turret vs. ships battle (only one, but I despised it… ok, ok… picky picky), the turret vs. Sith battle (Boooo!) and the ridiculously laborious swoop racing. Ugh. Your mileage may vary, but I truly despise those mini-games. Pazaak is still fun nevertheless. I also did not enjoy the random loot. There is a whole heck of a lot of it; and it is mostly irritating junk. Don't hate, bro. That's just how I see it.

[i]Kotor II[/i] is entertaining. I just have a grand time playing. I find it fun visiting the planets, engaging in quests, and fighting for a better (or worse) tomorrow for the Republic.

If you want to give it a go, there are some very talented mod makers who create quality of life, gameplay, and graphic upgrades. Since [i]The Sith Lords[/i] was rushed and incomplete, I truly recommend the restored content and detailed mod installation guides.

For me, this is how a Star Wars game should be made.

Whether you are a Star Wars fan or not, whether you played the first KOTOR or not, I firmly believe this is a MUST PLAY game for anyone who has the time and means.

When I was younger, it was just because the Star Wars brand and universe, but as an adult I can see this game has a significant amount of depth and philisophical questions. This game can be a mindlessly played title of the Star Wars genre, but if you give pause while playing and actual think on some of the dialogue and the interpreted teachings of good and evil, I believe this game can mature the mind.

The gameplay is clunky and dated, the combat uses a DnD 3.5 derivitive, but for a game released in the early 2000's, this was an underrated masterpiece.

KOTOR II is not just some game, it's an experience that only grows better as time passes.

132106188.review:
This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ♥♥♥♥ing minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you

131771847.review:
"Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic 2: The Sith Lords" is a masterpiece of a game that deserves a spot on any list of the greatest games of all time. From the moment the game starts, players are sucked into a rich and compelling story that will keep them hooked until the very end. The game's characters are well-written and likable, and players will quickly develop a connection to them as they make decisions that shape the course of the story.

The combat system is smooth and satisfying, the graphics and sound design are top-notch, and the role-playing elements are deep and engaging. The game's story is a true standout, with a complex and well-crafted narrative that will have players questioning their choices and their allegiance to the light or dark side of the force. The game's story is rich, complex, and has a real impact on the outcome of the game.

"Knights of the Old Republic 2" is a must-play game for any fan of role-playing games. It's an experience that will stay with you long after the credits roll and one you will want to play again and again. The game is a true testament to the power of storytelling in video games and stands as one of the best examples of the genre.

131744810.review:
I don't know if this is a hot take or not, but I think this game is a great improvement over the first. While it shares many aspects, and I think the first one's story has a much better endgame, Sith Lords manages to have a much better flow to its gameplay loop, and also unlike the first game, I actually want to return to it and do another playthrough. Overall, I had a lot more fun in the minute to minute gameplay compared to KOTOR 1, which honestly felt more novelty then pure fun. Additionally, I think your party is a bit more memorable than the first game, although I think that might just be my personal preference.

My biggest complaint (aside from the bugs, which I still believe to be the biggest detractor for both this game and the previous) is that it doesn't really feel "complete". Almost like I was missing large parts of the game and story, and planets felt a lot smaller than they should've been, while "dungeons" (locations where there is nothing to do but kill and loot) felt empty and a bit too long for what they needed to be.

With all that said, however, if you had fun with the first game, I think I can confidently recommend this one as well.

131312021.review:
There are aspects and themes to this masterpiece that still walk with me to this day. Star Wars can be something truly profound and meditative if it’s given to the right people, and Obsidian knew exactly how to paint that picture on an empty canvas. It’s this game that made me fascinated by the philosophical impact that this genre can create, and there was a brief time when a whole list of RPG’s came out that had the same spirit of life and a deeper meaning. I played this game to completion one time and never wanted to touch it again, because I’ll never have the same experience. If you’ve never played KOTOR 2, this is the prime RPG that surpasses everything else. Star Wars was once something really special, and if games could have a soul, you can feel it in this one. It inspired me to strive for more.

Now, since I’ve got the flattery out of the way, there’s one tip: No matter how thoughtful or seemingly wise Kreia is, you shouldn’t listen to everything she says. You make your own choices for the future you want to create, and Kreia will only incentivize to look after yourself as she was once a Sith. She’ll still call you through the Force, but just put her in her room to mumble to herself, and take Atton and Visas. You can make your own destiny.

131308750.review:
This is a Star Wars game like you won't provably will ever see again. No evil empire, no Darth Vader, no Palpi or Luke, Leia or that product of incest Rey. It doesn't make references to the movies, it doesn't need them. It's a Star Wars game that makes it so the galaxy feels truly so big characters exists seamlessly on their own within the universe without stumbling upon some cameo or hint to the movies. 

The writing is pretty good, Kreia is a complex character and without spoiling anything, she moved me with a few words coming from her at the end, it meant so much to me. I went from really liking the game to completely loving it. 

Final words, get the cut content community patch and the unofficial community patch, it makes a world of difference.

131131219.review:
This highly anticipated sequel lives up to the hype!

I love this game, even more so than the masterpiece that was the original. If I had to describe this game in one sentence, it would be: "The king of dialogue."

This game takes the lore and character-writing from the first game and expands upon it ten-fold.
Characters are incredibly complex, and you truly have to work to get to know them and get them to open up more. I love the introduction of the "influence" system; your words and actions will affect your party members, sometimes in surprising ways.

The story, while incredibly dark and somewhat depressing at times, is wrapped in mystery; even the shady past of your own player character is revealed in snippets, hinted at until you can uncover the story of what really happened to you.

Gameplay is pretty much copy-pasted from the first game (no complaints there, why mess with a good thing?), only this time, skills are actually useful; you will find yourself alone in many instances, and skills that once seemed unnecessary will be put to the test.

The only real flaw I can think of, is this game has a rather anti-climactic ending. It is rather ambiguous, which is frustrating considering how much time it took to uncover the meat of the story. Even so, I loved every minute of it.

A must-play for fans of the original.

130037405.review:
This game is amazing, addictive and VERY well-made. 
Someone said it is the "best star wars movie" and i couldn't agree more. Be as it may with all the technical limitations of it's time, the game shines as a true spectacle of character building, narrative and design. 
In order to avoid spoillers, all i want to evaluate here is the impact KOTOR 2 had on both my view of Star Wars and of the ways in which storytelling can be crafted for playing. 
First of all: I feel as if this was the essential bit of content that the franchise needed to leave a strong impression in me. Even from the perspective of 2023 and all the new stuff coming out, I was never impressed about the way in which their stories were built or delivered because they never got to change the nature of perspective and leave the hero-villain tunnel for a more wild and free storytelling of how the forces of status quo and chaos might play out. This is all personal taste, of course, but it leads me to appreciate even more of the capacities of a player-based medium, because only as a game it could have been possible to challenge a long tradition of archetypical narration and boring characters, only as a game does the storytelling invites us to think of how perspective is an inherent bond and neutrality is impossible.
I recognize, of course, that the story is built of all the typical characters Star Wars content has to offer, but the effects of maneuvering through the complex array of choices and motivations as the exile, the one who unites these people and directs them (in a gameplay sense), is what really attracted me. Honestly, it'sooooo cool to explore all the ways in which one could fight, talk, and get to know the rich lore KOTOR has to offer; I loved to feel immersed in the technical aspects of gameplay when we build our fighting scheme and allignments. 
Well, this far i mostly talked about how games where choice matters are awesome, and indeed they are, but there's something in KOTOR that makes it feel even more special: the narrative. The story of a Jedi exile who roams the galaxy forever alone for reasons to be discovered, and overcome, is great!!! Really, we as players are allowed to fit perfectly into the galaxy far far way because of great design choices that led storytelling in a direction that challenges perspective, makes it intovbonding. The characters of this world are not just figures of a lager myth, but perspectives in which we throw ourselves and by whom we  try to understand this huge world, and our role in it. 
Well, i feel i've talked too much about it (even though i played it for 50 hours and that's crazy, I never do that), but there's always more to be gained from experiencing it. KOTOR 2 took a good week out of my vacations and it was worth it!

129310022.review:
Please give this game a chance before you quit on Peragus.

This game plays terribly; dated MMO combat, game breaking technical issues at high frame rates, and the obviously bad 2003 graphics. Yet, it's one of the most interesting RPGs I've ever played.

The writing of this game is the star of the show; Kreia being the obvious crown jewel of it. Still, there's a lot more to get out of this game than just her, and if you plan to play it I implore you to explore the stories of every party member and try to get their influence up as much as you can (which means going out of your way to use them, don't just rely on your Jedi friends to help you). 

Unlike the original KOTOR, there are almost no standout side quests, but I think that actually works out in the end. The writers are much more focused on characters in this game, and because of that, all the quests (even the main one) are designed with the intention of showing off your party members' personal philosophies; with them frequently interjecting and arguing with your choices. This would also happen in the first game, but with the addition of the influence system it actually makes a difference this time; it also doesn't just devolve into lightside-darkside bickering like it always would in that game. The influence system is just genius--you being able to change your party members' force affinities adds so much depth to the game, and allows for so many more possibilities in how your party ends up. I hate that other RPGs don't follow in this one's footsteps when it comes to your party; it's the best ever. Also for those who are fans of Fallout: New Vegas, you will be happy to know that skill based dialogue options actually originate from this game, and are as good as you would hope (spec into wisdom if you want more dialogue btw).

The main quest's ending is unfinished, plain and simple. The restored content mod (which you can easily add from the Steam Workshop) tries to alleviate this, but it can only do so much. Bao-Dur's fate is never explained, HK-47's final segment is a slog, it's so disjointed that almost nothing makes any sense, and it's ultimately an anti-climactic finish to what should have been a clear home-run wrap-up to everything that was so expertly setup. But what is there is great, and I'm glad if anything that Kreia's plot was fully completed--seems that was the main objective for them.

It may seem like I'm torn on whether or not to like this game, but no it's great. A must play if you like RPGs, not just if you like Star Wars. I could see someone waiting for an inevitable remake (arguable whether or not it's inevitable), and you would definitely get a better experience, but what is here is definitely worthwhile even today.

129139976.review: Whatever story this game is so critically acclaimed for is not worth the time spent tolerating its awful combat, every fight is long, drawn out and tedious. combat is turned based and randomly rolls numbers to assess whether you will hit or miss targets. The combat is like watching a movie rather than playing a game, you have minimal control and it is needlessly time-wasting. The world-building, like most obsidian games, is the main essence of the game; in order to experience the world-building players must endure the first 2 chapters, spanning a minimum of 4 hours if all areas and quests are fully explored. These areas are monotonous and the quests are linear but provide 2 paths, each that will always play out the same way. Dialogue options will change variably for seemingly no reason, players cannot choose to engage in combat, the other characters of the game will always initiate. Player micro-agency is minimized and instead the only meaningful choices lie on the grander scale such as which faction you will align with. I wish I could reclaim both the time and money spent on this game. A similar game I'd recommend over this would be Outer Worlds; it has awful writing yet is still a much better game.

128503670.review:
I have played this game (and its predecessor) over decades much, much more then Steam counter shows. For me it’s one of GOATs. It just hit me that KotOR series is basically a forerunner for Mass Effect. Of course, ME is using newer/better engine and gameplay is different, much more leaning to action game then RPG, but there are a lot of similar gameplay mechanics to be found.

For those not aware, the series is set ~ four thousand years before the original Star Wars films, telling the story of the conflict between the original (Old) Republic and the Sith Empire (or so you would think). But as one character explains, conflict was never between Siths and Republic, but between Siths and Jedi Order, and Republic is just collateral damage.
This timeline has some of the most memorable bad guys in all of Star Wars. One is Darth Sion, a “walking corpse” Sith Lord who is for all things and purposes immortal, shear force of his hate for everything, everyone and their mothers is keeping him alive/in one piece. Second is Darth Nihilus, essentially a Sith ghost, with very cool mask, who eats planets, or to be more precise, all the life from the hole planet, bacteria, and everything else included. There is excellent comic series published by Dark Horse comics, “Star Wars: The Old Republic” consisting of ~50 episode, that expands story of first game and explains some things that are happening in second one.

If you, like me, are fan of dark humour and irony in abundance, you will adore HK-47. That droid deserves his own (comedy?) show on Disney+. Writer(s) responsible for him should get some award for life achievement.

[i]"Recitation: Yes, as I said, I am an assassin droid. It is my primary function to burn holes through meatbags that you wish removed from the galaxy… Master. Oh, how I hate that term."[/i]

[i]"Mockery: Am I all right? Oh, yes, Master, why, I am fine. Statement: I mean, I have only just been re-activated, only to find that there are sub-standard duplicates of me running all over the galaxy, corroding my good name. But if they are, in fact, hunting you, then I look forward to the opportunity to meet these units—and educate them in proper assassination protocols."[/i] ~ HK-47

Contrary to the first game, in KOTOR 2 you explore the dark(er) side of the galaxy and results of the war from the first game. To some extent, dialogs get to be philosophical in explorations of cause and effect that is often overlooked in other Star Wars games and especially movies. You get to realise that to the rest of the galaxy Jedi and Siths are same thing. People of Dantooine despise the Jedi for things that the Siths have done. In their eyes these are “two factions of same religion”, to use that metaphor, as almost all Siths are fallen Jedi. KotOR 2 is, at least to my knowledge, one of few games that try to depict how conflict changes people and world/galaxy.

Mandalorian war, that predates events of first game was in essence covert campaign for converting Jedi to Sith. Jedi would be mentally broken (if not physically) as results of being surrounded with killing and death on such scale, after which they would just “slide” to the dark(er) side. Most of the game’s important characters are veterans or had their lives and identities shattered by warfare. KotOR 2 feels like the closest Star Wars ever comes to recognising the endless cycle of war, death, and destruction that the Sith and Jedi have doomed the galaxy to.

 Only thing that was left for me to say, for any first-timer or someone who is returning after long time it that “TSL Restored Content Mod” is a MUST and with it opportunity to play one mission solo as HK-47 in quest “HK-50 factory”. “M4-78 Enhancement Project” is fascinating peace of moding, but it’s too buggy for my liking and I had a lot of problems with it :-/. 
Other things that you should “install” are “KotOR 2 Remastered (AI Upscaled) Cutscenes”, “KotOR 2 Unlimited World Texture Mod”, “High Quality Skyboxes II”, “K2 Portrait Restored”, “Ultimate Character Overhaul -REDUX-“, “Ultimate Dantooine High Resolution”, “Ultimate Dxun High Resolution”, “Ultimate Korriban High Resolution”, “Ultimate Malachor V High Resolution”, “Ultimate Onderon High Resolution” and finally “Ultimate Nar Shaddaa High Resolution”.

Don’t expect to see Witcher 3 level of graphics after this texture packs are in place, after all this is game from 2005, but it is much nicer than original ones.
Over & out.

The first time I played the game back in the day it ended after killing the 4 Jedi masters, spazzing out during a cutscene, and I literally took that to be THE END OF THE GAME. 128428496.review:
Knights of the Old Republic II, or KoToR II, is a beloved and critically-acclaimed video game that has earned a place in the hearts of fans and the pantheon of gaming greats. Set in the Star Wars universe, KoToR II follows the journey of a Jedi who must use the power of the Force to battle evil and save the galaxy from destruction.

What sets KoToR II apart from other games in the Star Wars franchise is its deep and complex storyline, which features a wide array of engaging and well-developed characters. The game also offers players a high degree of freedom and choice, allowing them to shape the story and the fate of the galaxy through their actions and decisions.

Another standout feature of KoToR II is its combat system, which combines action-packed battles with strategic elements, allowing players to customize their characters and abilities to suit their playstyle. The game also features a wide variety of locations, weapons, and enemies, making each playthrough a unique and exciting experience.

Overall, KoToR II is a must-play for fans of the Star Wars franchise and role-playing games. Its compelling story, engaging characters, and deep gameplay make it a true classic of the genre, and a game that will continue to be enjoyed by players for years to come.

126070778.review:
This RPG is nearly 20 years old, but holds up extremely well. The graphics have also aged well for a game created in 2004 due to the style that the developers chose, which is slightly cartoony but realistic enough to take seriously. 

The companions are more compellingly written and more interactive than most RPGs that I have ever played, both old and modern. My favorites were Atton, Kreia, the Handmaiden and Visas (in no particular order). Even the player character has a backstory, and although some details are set, you get the opportunity to determine this backstory through dialogue (which feels uniquely reactive). 

The plot of the game is very intriguing, because its key characters defy and criticize the Light Side (typically Jedi) / Dark Side (typically Sith) binary of Star Wars. It has a political backstory that you actually care about, unlike the Prequel movies. Still, the game ultimately suffers from the very LS/DS binary that its characters nearly break down. For example, the dialogue is usually nuanced, but sometimes boils down to "I will help you!" or "I will kill you!" with nothing in-between. This is very forgivable in the grand scheme of things.

My only problems with this so far are on gender locking (ex: gender-locked companions), the sexualization of female characters, and the small amount of content. Sparse content make sense for a game created in 2004, especially one that was as rushed as KOTOR 2, but the sexualization in the character design and interactions of some of the companions is incredibly ridiculous, especially for characters who are otherwise very well-written.

Definitely play this game if you want a very compelling party-based RPG. There are some underdeveloped or flatly ridiculous parts, but these are minor bumps on a great ride.

124587922.review:
I suspect The Last Jedi took 'inspiration' from Chris Avellone's interpretation of the Star Wars Universe in KotOR 2, but this is unequivocally better executed in almost every way. Coming off hot from Bioware's KotOR 1, this game turns it up to 11 and flips the typical Star Wars story formula on it's head, turning a rather simplistic light vs dark space fantasy adventure story into a darker and more nuanced interpretation of the universe. Instead of being a galactic adventure like in the first game, this game's story is more focused on isolation and survival against hidden forces. It's a very introspective story that questions a lot of the norms presented in the SW universe.

The gameplay is based on 3rd edition D&D and is piss easy. For newer players, you might find it challenging until just over halfway, where enemies inexplicably stop scaling with your level and cap out at level 20. I suspect this was carried over from the first game when the level cap was 20. The result is the later half of the game becomes a snooze-fest with no real challenge. The real challenge comes in understanding the game's archaic mechanics and how effectively build your character. There's a few options for different builds which lends to replayability, along with the choice to play either light or dark (Not neutral, though, unless you like gimping your build).

Soundtrack is fully orchestral, sounds great but the ingame music looping can feel a bit janky.

It is a must to play this with Restored Content mod. The retail release is an incredibly stripped down version of what was meant to be. I don't know what it is with old school Obsidian, but they must have loved taking on projects with short deadlines because this has to be one of the most unfinished games ever released. From gameplay issues, to entire plotlines and character arcs staying unresolved forever (For example, the HK Factory existed in the retail release, but was totally inaccessible in-game no matter what, and rather than removing all references to it, the plot-line just hangs midway for eternity with no way to resolve it.), its just not worth playing vanilla for an objectively inferior experience. TSLRCM takes cut dialogue, voice lines, maps, items, quests (both side & main) etc... that was already on-disk and puts it all back where it was supposed to be in a cohesive way. It's not perfect, and not everything made it back in, but it's an incredible feat to be able to restore the game as close to it's intended vision as possible, and even the original developers themselves endorse this mod as the definitive way to play!

124336574.review:
Star Wars and Nietzsche

a really inverse narrative to the precedent star wars narratives revolving around the mythological heroic journey and really star wars in general 

not to say its a subversion of the franchise but I enjoy how it commentates on elements of the force and its 2 polarizing ideologies and the paradoxes they have ingrained in them flawed as they are

the Jedi teaches apathy and detachment from emotions but this becomes a double-edged sword for making those same Jedi easier to fall to the dark side due to a life of suppressing and denying emotion 

the sith's paradox is the constant power without purpose to the point where it wields you not the other way around which is also an extension to the force and how despite the many sith and Jedi using the force as a tool in the end it uses them in its will to achieve a balance within itself which usually leaves insurmountable suffering in its wake as millions die to achieve a transient balance for a time till the pendulum of the universe continues to swing

in some ways its a bit of a stab at religion with how religion mostly pagan Christianity teaches a sort of similar apathy towards life denoting heaven afterlife and to simply sit and wait for heaven to come

in this sense, the narrative of the exile cutting themself off from the force is a very Nietzsche-themed death of god subtext of living with your own purpose with the death of god instilling purpose unto people 

their own purpose, not a subservient one 

and in the end what is the force in star wars except for a metaphysical quantification of God albeit instead of an individualistic moniker it's more a supernatural extension of metaphysical energy binding the galaxy in a web of intricacy where one action at a certain place and time causes echos to reverberate

ngl the game is a bit glitchy sometimes with bugs like being stuck in corners and the inability to move after battle sometimes unless you use a combination of controls to unstuck your characters not to mention they're are ways to undermine the difficulty of bosses

though I do enjoy the ability to characterize my own experience as with any RPG especially a rich lore narrative like Knights of the Old Republic 2 

the game feels extremely short but this is based on a first playthrough and I believe I missed a portion of content which I will attempt to revisit and actively lookout for in a second run 

all in all, highly recommend the first Knights of the Old Republic and the second installment as well since they both play off each other in a fugue-like manner with the second game contrasting many of the romanticized heroic tones of the first game contrasted with a more speculative and gray understanding of situations and powers at work

122675376.review:
So for a sequel of the original first game, as it came out in 2004 (a year later, after the first game) and created by another studio known as “Obsidian Entertainment”, the people who made Fallout: New Vegas. This game is better than the first one, as the story itself is quite interesting. Though the ending (without spoilers) didn’t set me right, as it did leave off as a hinting of continuation for the third installment (which spoiler alert, the game was canceled long ago. So it will never see the day of light ever again). Graphics have been improved, combat is even better, and the companions are quite fleshed out. They’re quite humorous and even have more character than the first one, as the first one they did but most of the time either argue or just annoy the hell out of you. 

But this game is more fleshed out, as the atmosphere was quite outstanding. Even seeing the outside of Ebon Hawk from inside while warping lightspeed. It gave areas more life and depth, than like the stereotypical 2d background. There’s more stuff you could do and even the stuff they brought back from the first game. They took the time to even expand it like swoop bike racing. Even though the story is longer than the first one, it feels easier to level up and gain credits. Since the first game it took maybe 2-3 hours to see a level up.  Now in this game you would see a level up every hour or so, depending on your grinding XP. 

Now onto the cons of things. They did fix the cutscene problems I had, but the dialogue is still a problem. Such as if the game has been running for too long, as sometimes if you get into dialogue. It goes into mach 5 and skips every line of dialogue, as if you are spamming the mouse to the point that your finger bone is broken in many ways. Which leaves you dumbfounded at the end of picking a choice of dialogue to something you didn’t get a single lick of knowledge about. It irritated me, as you have to save and restart the whole game. Which would fix it temporarily for the time being. Another slight bug, which I didn’t mention in the first game review. That after combat, you just get stuck out of nowhere. Such that you don’t move anymore, but the only way to fix that is just to press X to make your character flex then it will fix itself. 

Now for the rating of this game, which is 9/10. Because the cutscene bugs or crashes from the first game didn’t transfer over, but the original story of the first is a bit better, as this one is still really good. It just the story on this one still kinda left me scratching my head at times.

122168188.review:
The first jewel in Obsidian’s crown, this is an absolute must for any Star Wars fan, and one of the finest video games ever made, despite being unfinished.

To really understand KOTOR 2, you have to throw yourself back in time a bit. When KOTOR released, Revenge of the Sith hadn’t come out yet, and the notion that Jedi and Sith were two sides of the same coin was still an uncomfortable one for much of the audience. 

On top of that, there were several popular Star Wars games at the time (like Jedi Knight) that let you make the choice to play as a Light Side or Dark Side user. These games were VERY binaristic. You could be a saint who wouldn’t hurt a fly…or you could butcher orphans. Nuance wasn’t exactly thick in the air - these stories tended towards schlocky escapism.  

KOTOR 2 took an active stance against this trend. Light or Dark, Jedi or Sith, whoever you are is immaterial - the story of this game was written to challenge your commitment to an absolute philosophy. Your fantasies of pure good and pure evil are not welcome here.

The heart and soul of the game is Kreia, the mysterious old woman who appoints herself your mentor. She has no interest in teaching you how to be a Jedi Knight - she’s more interested in teaching you how to be a human being. Almost twenty years on and people are still arguing about Kreia online - by that metric, I’d call her one of the most successful characters in video games.

Sure, on the surface, this is an incredible party-building RPG with lightsaber and blaster based combat. Underneath that, it’s a philosophical treatise, nestled within one of the largest and most successful intellectual properties of all time. It took what Lucas started and ran with it.

Tragically, corporate greed saw this game rushed out the door for Christmas before it was finished, but the momentum behind KOTOR is so huge that a restored content mod was eventually released, and I would highly recommend playing with it. This is from the first Xbox generation, and though it has aged beautifully, the lack of polish is glaringly obvious at times.

Simply put, KOTOR 2 is one of the most elegant and well-renowned examples of ‘meta-narrative’ ever crafted. It redefined everything.

Bring on the remake!

121839034.review:
Kotor 2 has had a weird journey.  First it was released only 2/3rds finished to meet an unrealistic deadline.  Then the patch that was supposed to finish the game was cancelled by LucasArts.  The game languished unfinished, but still loved, for years.

Then, lo and behold, modders finished "The Sith Lord Restored Content Mod" which took a lot f that unfinished content and well... finished it.  It also dropped a lot of bug fixes as well, and while the game still had problems, it could at last be called a finished product.  

Shortly thereafter, the impossible happened.  The company that made the PC port was given the funds to actually *upgrade* the game to run on modern systems.  While not a true HD remaster, it did provide widescreen support and did some bug fixing of its own.  This is nearly unheard of, especially from EA, who tends to let games that don't meet GTA-like sales figures go unsupported as not worth their time. 

Combine that with the continued efforts of its PC modding community, and Kotor 2 is one of the best RPGs you can play.  It does have its rough spots.  How much you like it will depend on how well you receive an incredibly preachy and sanctimonious character who will lecture you non-stop about their philosophy on the Star Wars universe.  Anyone familiar with Chris Avellone's work will instantly be familiar with this character type (See Ulysses from Fallout New Vegas and Durance from Pillars of Eternity for other examples).  Some think she's the greatest character ever.  I personally find her insufferable and obnoxious, and a prime example of how her writer has his head a little too far up his own ass at times.  

What makes her frustrating is, that unlike the other two, you have to actively cater to her whims and kiss her ass to get enough influence to unlock additional dialogue which goes a great deal to explaining the game's backstory, and even character motivations.  So if you do like I want to do, and just tell her to shut up, and leave her on the ship, you'll be missing important chunks of narrative.  

If you don't mind humoring her, or actually like her, then the game's biggest narrative issue is pretty minor.

A grilled cheese consists of only these following items. Cheese. Bread with spread (usually butter). This entire subreddit consist of "melts". Almost every "grilled cheese" sandwich i see on here has other items added to it. The fact that this subreddit is called "grilledcheese" is nothing short of utter blasphemy. Let me start out by saying I have nothing against melts, I just hate their association with sandwiches that are not grilled cheeses. Adding cheese to your tuna sandwich? It's called a Tuna melt. Totally different. Want to add bacon and some pretentious bread crumbs with spinach? I don't know what the hell you'd call that but it's not a grilled cheese. I would be more than willing to wager I've eaten more grilled cheeses in my 21 years than any of you had in your entire lives. I have one almost everyday and sometimes more than just one sandwich. Want to personalize your grilled cheese? Use a mix of different cheeses or use sourdough or french bread. But if you want to add some pulled pork and take a picture of it, make your own subreddit entitled "melts" because that is not a fucking grilled cheese. I'm not a religious man nor am I anything close to a culinary expert. But as a bland white mid-western male I am honestly the most passionate person when it comes to grilled cheese and mac & cheese. All of you foodies stay the hell away from our grilled cheeses and stop associating your sandwich melts with them. Yet again, it is utter blasphemy and it rocks me to the core of my pale being. Shit, I stopped lurking after 3 years and made this account for the sole purpose of posting this. I've seen post after post of peoples "grilled cheeses" all over reddit and it's been driving me insane. The moment i saw this subreddit this morning I finally snapped. Hell, I may even start my own subreddit just because I know this one exists now.

You god damn heretics. Respect the grilled cheese and stop changing it into whatever you like and love it for it what it is. Or make your damn melt sandwich and call it for what it is. A melt.

This game is a delight to return to, back when star wars was a scifi fantasy and free from the stench of diabetically sweet didney worl. It's showing its age and has some problems/bugs, but the story and dialogue are a treat.
For a brief moment you could almost be forgiven for forgetting that: if there ever was a KotOR3 to continue from this story, it would only be a retconned disneyfied nightmare hooked up to be milked long past its funeral. Find solace that it once was, my padawan.

Here is a spoiler free appraisal of the story:
The force: "Owwww!" *screams*
The Jedi: "bbbut me scawed :("
The Sith: "feeeed me >:|"
Your allies: "she's...she's turning you evil, dude."
Atris: "Sith? no way, YOU'RE a sith!"
Sith holocrons: *unintelligible yelling*
T3: "beep boop"

Play it and be evil, one-up the baddies (wish we could wear that mask!)
Play it and be neutral, let the money guide you (someone's happier if you go grey anyway).
Play it and be good, rise above the squabbles and heal the galaxy (you'll get a chance to out jedi the jedi).

120792659.review:
[h1]Greatest Star Wars media - free from George Lucas and Disney[/h1]
[b]There were times when Star Wars was all about compelling stories and rich lore which mirrored real world history and philosophy. The unfinished classic Knights of the Old Republic II from Obsidian is arguably one of the best stories from SW Legends and any media in general.[/b]

KOTOR2 turns Lucas' pure good/pure evil false dichotomy into moral playground that makes you question everything. The story is an intensely philosophical and reflection on war and morality. This is achieved thanks to the masterfully written dialogues. Every major character you meet frequently raises questions of responsibility and complicity, often manipulating the character/player and leaving it open for you to think about the choices you made and the nature of the Force itself. A great example is the philosophy and story of Kreia which highly mirrors the book from Friedrich Nietzsche – [b]“Thus Spoke Zarathustra: A Book for All and None”[/b] and the concept of the Übermensch. The interwoven plot and rich storytelling of KOTOR2 couldn’t be possible in any other media which proves that video game can indeed be art.

The only downside is that when KOTOR2 was released it wasn't complete due to LucasArts pressuring the developers for an early Christmas release date. Many parts of the game were cut out. But thanks to hard-core Star Wars fans out there they made the TSLRCM which is easy to download from Steam Workshop and allows you to play the game with the cut-out parts.
 
Outside of being unfinished, KOTOR2 hasn’t really aged well. The combat feels dated and it’s too easy even on the highest difficulty. You’ll die very little, outside some boss fights, and this leaves you feeling as if you are playing on rails. Dialogues are skipped over at unreadable speed when you play for couple of hours which is apparently some kind of bug where memory starts leaking. 

[b]Knights of the Old Republic II is a “must play” tier RPG and the greatest piece of Star Wars media that Disney will never acknowledge. Let’s hope for a proper remake![/b]

[i]There must always be a Darth Traya. One who holds the knowledge of betrayal, who has been betrayed and will betray in turn.[/i]

120581466.review:
Never played it back when it came out, however for years and years I heard this is not only a fantastic game from Obsidian but arguably one of the best Star Wars games ever made.
I'm not a fan of Star Wars but Obsidian and the prospect of what they could do with the lore surrounding those movies was a pretty enticing prospect, that I absolutely wanted to explore AND YOU SHOULD TOO!
It's janky as all fuck (keeping in mind it's from 2003) but the situations you are put in are incredibly interesting and well written.
Choices feel deep, diverse and impactful.
It's almost like Mass Effect at times if I'm completely honest.
However, the first maybe 2 - 4 hours are a little long and can be difficult and possibly at times frusturating.
It suffers from the early 2000's issues of back tracking and really hands off gameplay as far as the combat goes.
Most of the time you will end up cheesing the game in order to circumvent most fights and make them easier than they were possibly intended to be.
I still haven't finished the game but I do fully intend to, I will say however about 8 hours in I went from Hard difficult to Medium because it became so unbearably irritating and unfun to play.
Then maybe 20 or 30 hours in I changed it to easy.
I know this feels like a shitty thing to say, especially as someone who tries to play everygame ESPECIALLY RPGS on the hardest difficult available for 2 reasons: I love the challenge/ feeling of accomplishment and I personally feel it immerses me further into the world and game when I really have to care about my health and the decision I make that may put me in poor situations that could have me winding up dead.
Don't be like my stubborn ass.
There is 0 reason to play this on any other difficult than the easiest, maybe it's because I've grown so accustomed to modern games, but the combat feels incredibly iffy and out of my hands to the point that it comes down to luck at certain times.
The game as a whole is a masterpiece even with the shitty as fuck combat.
If you can handle the slow beginning of the game just FOR A BIT, you will become a true fan of this game for the things it absolutely does right.
I would take the garbage combat and graphics any day for the depth this game provides.
This game deserves the praise I've heard over the years.
This game is a time sink in terms of how engrossed you will become in it.
This is the end of this review.
No idea how you made it to the end of it.

I believe it's truly the best written video game ever made. KOTOR 2 takes the world of Star Wars and explores it more thoughtfully, more philosophically than any other game that I've played has. I've often joked that it's the third best Star Wars movie; after this most recent playthrough, I now say in all sincerity that it's the second best. Yes, the game is buggy and unfinished. I highly encourage downloading some of the community content to assist with the issues and restore missing content. However, if you allow yourself to fall into this game and do at least one playthrough maxing out Kreia's influence, you'll never find a more thought-provoking character.

This review has been rambling but, to get to the point, despite all of the game's flaws, I do believe this is the best Star Wars game ever made and a true 5* classic that transcends the genre. Do yourself a favor and play this game.

120488757.review:
A grim but amazing story that continues the lore of Kotor 1 whilst criticizing the fundamental foundations of the Star Wars universe. 

An in depth examination of both the Sith and Jedi and how their beliefs ultimately lead to failure, the unseen cost of victory, the consequences of the hero's journey and the resulting trauma on the galaxy show that Star Wars is perfectly capable of telling much more mature and nuanced themes without losing its identity.

A beautiful - if not flawed - game (please use the TSL restored content mod), I highly recommend this to anyone if you are a fan of Legends and the Old Republic time period. Kotor 2 takes everything we know about this universe and turns it on it's head, whilst Kreia has to be one of the best fictional characters I have ever encountered. THIS is the game that made Revan the mystery that they are, not the original and certainly not the mmo. 9/10.

120486409.review:
A great sequel to KOTOR 1, but due to a limited time to develop the game, it has its flaws. I really liked the clunky combat system in the first KOTOR, but KOTOR 2 added and expanded on the combat system in a way which i liked. The game's deep and philosophical story was very interesting to explore, and while the game doesn't have a really good twist like the first, it really leaned in to new interpretations of the force and human empathy. I personally prefer KOTOR 2's characters more than the first, especially because of the game's new influence mechanic and because you can [spoiler]train certain members of the crew to be jedi[/spoiler]. The villains were incredibly unique and broke the mold. They challenged how to perceive the force and it's role in the galaxy. However, the end of the game leaves much to be desired. It is painfully obvious how low on time to work on the game near the end of KOTOR 2's story. Many plot points seem to have been rushed together or completely out of left field (and not in the good way). While the TSLRCM is a big help in making a more finished game, using cut content from the base game, it still is only a band-aid on a bullet wound. Some planets clearly have areas and quests completely cut out of the game. What's worse is that it will probably be the last KOTOR game ever, so some of the unanswered plot points leave a sour taste in my mouth. On top of all of that, Peragus is a very underwhelming and drawn out tutorial that turns you off to the rest of the game. It is overall a great game, but it's lack of development time sacrifices some of the amount of enjoyment you'll get from the story. KOTOR 2, if given just a little more development time, would have been a tremendous improvement compared to the first game and would clearly be the superior of the two. The uniqueness of the story made it a great Star Wars game and sequel. Even if they fumbled the bag on the ending act of the story and it could have been made a fuller game, it is probably my favorite KOTOR game. If you enjoyed the first KOTOR, you'll probably love this as well. 
9/10
