this game is super fun, the story is fantastic, big fan of the characters. I enjoyed it just as much, if not more than kotor 1. it's very user-friendly, though i would always suggest playing through kotor 1 before you jump into the sequel.

Concerning Mods:
i recommend playing this with the restoration mod, as it gives you a bit more content. this also added an unholy amount of HK-50 units to the game which CAN BE GOOD because they give you a lot of xp but by god it adds so many of them compared to the base game. 

I've gone through the game twice (at this point), with and without the M4-78 addition. Personally, I struggled to get through this planet and found myself incredibly frustrated by the end of it. i believe it's still a good addition to the game but by no means does it add any earth-shattering story elements. it's got some backtracking and puzzles to solve which can be tedious, but it's worth a shot to try it in at least one of your playthroughs.

i'm gonna detail a bit about playing the game as the female vs the male exile, nothing too spoiler-y but i'm still gonna hide it.

[spoiler] OVERALL, i GREATLY enjoyed my playthrough as the male exile compared to the female exile. characters treated me with more respect and there were more fulfilling story elements (IMO). there are some moving plot points that you see as the female exile, and i wouldn't ever suggest NOT playing as her. the female exile companion (the disciple) came off as more annoying that compelling and i often found myself wanting to skip through all his dialogue. the handmaiden on the other hand (the male exile companion) has a MUCH more interesting story, and i enjoyed her missions significantly more.

THIS IS ALL PERSONAL THOUGH! i don't want to discourage anyone from playing as the female exile, i just personally found the story beats in her path to be frustrating and a bit annoying.

while i didn't mention it in my kotor 1 review, the same can be said there. playing as the female main character in these games can be incredibly frustrating due to built-in sexism that the devs decided to include. it may not be a bother to everyone, but i'd prefer to not be harassed by my companions/npcs lol [/spoiler]

TL;DR, this game is amazing and i would suggest it for absolutely anyone, even people who don't traditionally like this kinda game style.

One of the greatest Star Wars games of all time, and one of the greatest rpgs in general IMO. KotOR 1 is better in many areas, though 2 is also better in many areas. Really, this best way is to just play both. I had no issues with this port, and it’s easy to add removed content from the workshop, which I recommend.
	The story is fantastic, a true Star Wars experience in every way. The characters are all great, complex and interesting. Light and dark side mechanics make you Feel the power of the darkside....or light. It’s decently open with exploration and travel. You pretty much get your own Falcon to use and operates as a fun hub for character interactions and crafting. Story choices matter. The crafting itself is as good as it need to be. 
	The actual combat I believe is where many will get turned off unfortunately. It operates as a real time with pause mechanics and a move queue. You can control the entire party, though you do not have too. I think it’s a blast. If your turned off by it, you should really consider spending some extra time playing before quitting. It will likely grow on you and become really fun if you do so.
	Overall any rpg fan or Star Wars fan should absolutely give these games a try. 1&2. And if your both, you Need to play these games.

119837588.review:
Apathy is death

TL;DR: The game is usually referred to just as KoTOR2 because of the crazy long title. The title is not the only crazy thing about the game - it was developed in a crazy short time, it was bugged like crazy(fixed now) and it is also crazy good. 
Fantastic even. Despite its short development time it's massive improvement over the first game - whether in gameplay, art direction, story, characters or just writing in general. Deals heavily with the themes of overcoming past trauma, but handles it incredibly well, with nuance.

After the great reception of the first game, released by Bioware in 2003, Obsidian got the chance to work on the second one - which was a great choice. The wrong choice was Lucasarts rushing the game out as fast as possible, forcing Obsidian to release the game in 2004, despite the original release date being in 2005. 
Game had 14-16 months of development, which is a really short time for a game of this size. As comparison, Dragon Age 2 had similar length of development and you know how copypaste and rushed that was.

Though the game was released in much rougher shape and was fixed over the years thanks to the fan mods. Those fan mods fix many bugs as well as restore a lot of cut content, resulting in meatier game. Since these mods are included by default with the Steam release, as well as support for higher resolutions(which KoTOR1 lacks), I think it's fine to take these in consideration when reviewing the game.
Despite that, the game still feels rushed, especially towards the end, and lacks better, more satisfying conclusion. Some of the cut content could have been handled better as well, such as HK Factory.

The game's plot's set few years after the first game, with the Jedi Order being on the brink of annihilation again. You play as the Exile - jedi veteran of Mandalorian wars - as they return from Jedi Council's mandated exile back into Republic space, instantly becoming a target of the new titular Sith Lords.  Except that the Exile isn't really a jedi anymore - they lost their connection to the force.  

Over the course of game you visit various planets and see how the Mandalorian and Jedi Civil War affected planets. You witness poverty, corruption, crime, refugees as well as people trying to rebuild, to get back on their feet, to recover. Which is the main theme of the game - moving on from past to the future and recovering. This theme is also reflected in (most) companions - who all were hurt and traumatised in the past and are trying to move on - as well as the Exile.

One companion who is especially stands out is Kreia - who serves as the foil to the choices you take - to provide different perspective on the Jedi, the Sith and the Force. This works because game is written with much more nuance than the previous game and it's way less cheesy Star Wars fare. 
A lot of concepts, cliches and tropes from SW or RPGs are flipped on their head, trying to make you think about them from different perspective. This results in the tone of game being much more sombre and mature compared to other SW media, which admittedly might not be to everyone's liking. Compared to the Last Jedi, it's much better as critique of SW, though to be fair, that's a very low bar.
Thankfully this also means the game should be fine for people who aren't fans or actually dislike Star Wars as well.

Audiovisually, the game is a great improvement over the first one. Not as much as in the graphical fidelity itself, but rather the art direction. Character designs are much better and Darth Nihilus is extremely iconic design. The fact that jedi robes actually look like robes in this one, flowing and loose as compared to sticky pajamas they were in KoTOR1, is a great improvement by itself.  A lot of assets are reused from the first game though, but that was pretty common at that time.
Music is another thing that differs from usual SW thing and helps set the tone really well. My favourite track is "Rebuilt Jedi Enclave", and it's very memorable and encapsulates the sombre tone of the game perfectly.

Gameplay-wise there have been improvements as well. The UI is easier to navigate, you can keep two sets of weapons to switch instantly between, new feats such as finesse and more. The biggest overhaul is probably in the crafting and upgrade system. Weapons now have more slots for upgrades and there are multiple types of upgrades for each slot, allowing for much more in-depth customisation of weapons and armour. 
Compared to the first KoTOR you also start already as a Jedi, with one of standard classes - Guardian, Sentinel or Consular. It's something I prefer more compared to starting as a class I won't really play one third of the game in.
On top of the standard jedi classes, there have been added prestige classes for both Jedi and the Sith, resulting in much bigger build variety, especially mixed with the new upgrade system.
Otherwise it's mostly identical to KoTOR1, but there was nothing to really fix there.

Overall, game is great and must-play whether you like Star Wars or RPGs. If you can handle bit of jank, you'll find that the game still holds up really well and is a lot of fun.

119674589.review:
It's an odd feeling playing The Sith Lords. The act of playing it, engaging with its mechanisms, is often fraught. There's numerous bugs and glitches, with some being minor and others requiring a game restart. The pacing is consistently inconsistent, with an incredibly sluggish and dull opening few hours that does its best to grind you down, as well as some other spots that are hampered by bizarre difficulty spikes that require a far more measured approach and culminating in an abrupt ending, albeit one that is conclusive for the main narratives and themes. 

In many ways the actual playing of the game might be the worst part, but at its lowest it's typically dull rather than out-right bad or unplayable. There are of course many moments where you're manipulating your party to full effect and leaping from one enemy to the other with a lightsaber in hand. It takes a while to get there, but it is fun when you do. And hey, they kept the flourish button for when you want to twirl around your lightsaber, which is a pointless but always fun distraction.

What makes TSL worth playing though, by far, is the writing. It inspects and critiques the conflicting dogma of the Jedi and the Sith, as well as dipping into a similar look at the genre of party-based RPGs. Through your ever growing group of adventurers and the events you find yourself caught in, TSL tries to highlight that slavish dedication to an absolute should not be seen as something admirable, more that it's important to understand what the general aim is of that absolute; doing 'good' things is not inherently reactive, whilst similarly you don't need to be assertive to do something 'evil'. 

Though it can take some time to really grapple with all of these themes, by the time the credits were rolling I was reflecting on all the characters in my group and all the events that had transpired. This is a game that uses the setting to talk about the setting itself, rather than as window dressing because lightsabers are cool and make fun sounds. They do, but what about the people who wield them? What's interesting about them?

The game is unquestionably flawed in ways that are too detrimental to ignore, but what's on offer here is something pretty rare for a game. As someone who is fairly ambivalent to Star Wars as a whole, there's a lot of fantastic ideas to tackle here. It's just a shame you've got to wade through so many problems to get there.

*Played through using the Restored Content mod*

119431418.review:
Great game. Get the remastered mod and it's easily one of (if not singularly) the best Star Wars game ever made. The first is also incredible but in the year 2023 it comes off a little too dated (deserves a solid remaster more than anything else) IMO.

I just finished the new Jedi Survivor game (solid but not great; ~40 hours to 100% and I have no intention to ever boot the game up again) and felt compelled to update my review for this old gem.

KOTOR2, to me, is the peak of the elusive gaming mountain of RPGs. 2 decades after release and there have only been a few contenders for more compelling story, characters, worlds, or gameplay. 
The story is rich and open, ignore-able to those that want to Force Run past everything but incredibly immersive and broad in scope for those that want to interact with everything. 

The main cast is potentially less interesting than the original KOTOR but still better than most modern RPGs. Choices cause changes that can be seen in the crew, specifically Handmaiden/Disciple and Atton have dramatic shifts and story plots based on their relationship with the Main Character. The sheer power of Kreias character and story arc (predictable as it is now-a-days), or the beloved comedic relief of the classic droids (and a few new ones).
These supporting characters are what leads to so much replayability, different party members have flavor lines and even cause different choices if they are in your party at different times which means sometimes 2 or 3 play-throughs in you might find a fun new dialog or interaction you missed.

The different worlds are fun but somehow feel smaller than the first game. That really just shows how much the original did with so little; the map sizes in this game are essentially the same as the new Jedi Survivor. But it still fun to explore the new zones, check out some of the planets you visited in the first game and see some of the repercussions to your actions there.

Good game.
